div.p: Acted in the yeare 1635. by the then Company of Revels, at Salisbury Court.
div.quote: Hic totus voloride at Libellus. Mart.
div.p: Printed by I. Okes, for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shops in Kings-street at the signe of the Goat, and in Westminster-hall. 1640.

div.head: To the Right Honourable WILLIAM Earle of New-Castle, &c. Governour to the Prince his Highnesse.
div.p:
YOur favourable Construction of my poore Labours commanded my Service to your Honour, and, in that, betray'd your worth to this Dedication: I am not ignorant how farre unworthy my best endeavours are of your least allowance; yet let your Lordship be pleased to know you, in this, share but the inconveniences of the most renowned Princes as you partake of their glories: And I doubt not, but it will more divulge your noble Disposition
to the World, when it is knowne you can freely pardon an Officious trespasse against your Goodnes. Caesar had never bin commended for his Clemency, had there not occasion beene offered, wherein hee might shew, how willingly hee could forgive: I shall thanke my Fortune, if this weake presentation of mine shall any way encrease the Glory of your Name among Good Men, which is the chiefest ayme and onely study of

closer.signed: Your Honours devoted servant. Richard Brome.

div.head: To his deserving friend Mr. Richard Brome on his Sparagus Garden, a Comedy.

lg.l: WHat ever walke I in your Garden use,
Breeds my delight, and makes me love thy Muse
For the designment; sith I cannot spie
A prospect, which doth more invite mine eye:
I'me in a maze, and know not how to find
A freedome that will more delight my mind,
Then this imprisonment within thy Bower,
Where houres seeme minutes, and each day an hower,
Nor, were my stay perpetuall, could I grieve,
Where such rare fruits mine appetite relieve.
The envious Criticke would recant to see
How much opprest is every virgin tree
With her owne burthen: Leekes, and Acornes here
Are food for Critickes; but the choycer cheere,
For those, can rellish Delicates I might
In praysing of thy worth, be infinite:
But thou art modest and disdain it to heare
A tedious, glorious, needlesse Character
Of thee and of thy Muse: Yet I could say,
(Give me but leave) it is no common Play.
Within thy plot of ground, no Weed doth spring,
To hurt the growth of any Vnderling:
Nor is thy Laborinth confus'd, but wee
In that disorder, may proportion see:
Thy Hearbs are physicall, and do more good.
In purging Humors, then some's letting blood.

div.head: To the Author on his Sparagus Garden.

lg.l: WHat dost meane, that thus thou dost entice
Thy Lovers, thus to walke in Paradice?
Most skilfull Artist! that so well dost know
To plant, for profit, as for out-ward show
For on thy Sparagus are throughly pleased
Our intellects; others scarce hunger eased.
The wisest of the Age shall hither come,
And thinke their time well spent as was their summe.
The Sqint-ey'd Criticke that such care do's take,
To looke for that he loatheth to partake:
Now crossing his warp'd Nature shall be kind,
And vexing grieve 'cause he no fault can find.
The ignorant of the times that do delight,
Not in a Play, but how to wast day-light,
Shall resort hither, 'till that you descry,
With pleasure, smiling April in each eye.
Alcinou's garden, which each day did spring,
And her lov'd fruit unto perfection bring,
Ought not compare with this: Here Men did grow:
Such care thy Arte and Labour did bestow
For man's wel-being, and a-new create,
And poyse them up above a needy Fate.
Is it not pitty ought should hurt this Spring?
(A Serpent in a Garden's no new thing)
Yet wisely hath thy goodnesse tooke a care,
He should sting none, but who censorious are.
HE, that his wonted modesty retaynes,
And never set a price upon his Braines
Above your Judgments; nor did ever strive
By Arrogance or Ambition to atchieve
More prayse unto himselfe, or more applause
Vnto his Scenes, then such, as know the Lawes
Of Comedy do give; He only those
Now prayes may scan his Verse, and weigh his Prose:
Yet thus far he thinks meet to let you know
Before you see't, the Subject is so low,
That to expect high Language, or much Cost,
Were a sure way, now, to make all be lost.
Pray looke for none: He'le promise such hereafter,
To take your graver judgments, now your laughter
Is all he aymes to moove. I had more to say-—
The Title, too, may prejudice the Play.
It sayes the Sparagus Garden; if you looke
To feast on that, the Title spoiles the Booke.
We have yet a tast of it, which he doth lay
I'th midst o'th journey, like a Bait by th' way:
Now see with Candor: As our Poet's free,
Pray let be so your Ingenuity.
AT first we made no boast, and still we feare,
We have not answer'd expectation here,
Yet give us leave to hope, as hope to live,
That you will grace, as well as Iustice give.
We do not dare your Iudgments now: for we
Know lookers on more then the Gamsters see;
And what ere Poets write, we Act, or say,
Tis only in your hands to Crowne a Play.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: With me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Onely a few neighbourly and friendly words sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Oh you are most friendly welcome good Mr. Gilbert Gilawire, and Mr. Walter Chamlet I take yee to be.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: The same sir at your service.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your fathers both were my good neighbours indeed; worthy and well reputed members of the City while they lived: but that may be read upon the Hospitall walls, and gates; it is enough for me to say they lov'd me: Sanson Touchwood! and I were a wretch if I should not honour their memory in their happy succession: Agen gentlemen you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yet you may be pleas'd sir to remember, though our fathers were both loving friends to you, yet they were sometimes at odds one with another.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: True, true, ever at odds: They were the common talke of the towne for a paire of wranglers; still at strife for one trifle or other: they were at law logger-heads together, in one match that held 'em tugging tone the tother by the purse-strings a matter of nine yeares, and all for a matter of nothing. They cours'd one another from Court to Court, and through every Court Temporall and Spirituall; and held one an other play till they lost a thousand pound a man to the Lawyers, and till it was very sufficiently ad judged that your father was one foole, and your father was another foole. And so againe gentlemen you are welcome: now your businesse.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: You may now be pleas'd sir to remember that our fathers grew friends at last.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And note the cause, the ground of their reconciliation, which was upon the love, betwixt me and this gentlemans sister. My fathers Sonne married his fathers Daughter, and our two fathers grew friends, and wise men agen.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: To the poynt good gentlemen, yet you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Troth sir the poynt is this: You know (and the towne has tane sufficient notice of it) that there has been a long contention betwixt you and old Mr. Striker your neighbour—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p:
And the cause or ground of your quarrell (for ought any body
knowes but your selves) may be as triviall, as that which was derided in our fathers.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Are you there with me?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And great hopes there are, and wagers laid by your friends on both sides, that you two will be friends.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ile hold you an hundred pounds o' that.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay, more, that Mr. Striker will bee willing to give his Grand-child to your Son, so you'l give your consent.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And your comming is to perswade that, is it not? if it be so, speake; deale plainely with me gentlemen, whilst yet you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Insooth it is so, we come to negotiate the match for your sonne, and your friendship with old Mr. Striker.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But when you weigh the reasons, and consider the perfect love of the yong paire, and how the world will praise your reconciliation, and blesse the providence, that made their loves the meanes to worke their parents charity.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Againe you are not welcome.

lg.l: Your selfe but now commended the attonement
Of our two fathers, wrought by the same meanes:
I meane my marriage with his sister here
Against as great an opposition.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But our fathers lov'd their children.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your fathers were a couple of doting fooles, and you a paire of sawcy knaves; now you are not welcome: and more then so, get you out of my doores.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you sir, by your wilfulnesse, cast away your sonne?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My sonne? no sonne of mine, I have cast him off already for casting an eye upon the daughter of mine enemy: let him goe, let him packe; let him perish: he comes not within these doores, and you, that are his fine spoken spokes-men, get you off o' my ground I charge you.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: We are gone sir: onely but wishing you Mr. Touchwood to remember that your sonne's your sonne.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Indeffinitely not sir, untill hee does not onely renounce all interest in the love of that baggage; but doe some extraordinary mischiefe in that family to right me for the trespasse hee has
done; and so win my good opinion, till which bee done a daily curse of mine hee shall not misse; and so you may informe him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What an uncharitable wretch is this?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: The touchiest peece of Touchwood that e're I met withall.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I fear'd we should inflame him.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: All the comfort is, his sonne may yet out-live him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: BUt the danger is, his father may dis-inherit him

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: He cannot be so devillish; here comes his sonne, a gentleman of so sweet a disposition, and so contrary to his crabbed Sire, that a man who never heard of his mothers vertue might wonder who got him for him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Not at all I assure you, Sam is his fathers nowne sonne: for the old man you see, is gentle enough, till he be incens'd; and the sonne being mov'd, is as fiery as the father.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But he is very seldome and slowly mov'd; his father often and o' the suddaine.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I prethee would'st thou have greene wood take fire as soone as that which is old and sere?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: He is deepe in thought.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Over head and eares in his Mrs. contemplation.

lg.l: To dis-obey a father, is a crime
In any sonne unpardonable. Is this rule
So generall that it can beare noe exception?
Or is a fathers power so illimitable,
As to command his sonnes affections?
And so controule the Conquerour of all men
Even Love himselfe? no: he, that enterprizes
So great a worke, forgets he is a man;
And must in that forget he is a father,
And so if he forgoe his nature, I
By the same Law may leave my Piety.
But stay, I would not lose my selfe in following
This wild conceit

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How now Sam, whither away?

lg.l: I was but casting how to find the way
Unto my selfe. Can you direct me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Yes, yes; your father has told us the way.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha you had conference with him? ha yee? speake.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Marry sir ha we, and I thinke to purpose.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha you wonne ought upon him to my advantage?

lg.l: As much as may restore you to acquaintance
With him againe, can you but make good use on't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pray doe not trifle with me; tell me briefly.

lg.l: Briefly he sayes you must not dare to see him;
Nor hope to receive blessing to the valew
Of a new three-pence, till you disclaime your love
In your faire Annabell; and not onely so,
But you must doe some villanous mischievous act
To vexe his adversary, her Grand-father;
Or walke beneath his curse in banishment.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A most uncharitable and unnaturall sentence.

lg.l: But thinke withall it is your father, that
Makes this decree; obey him in the 'execution:
He has a great Estate, you are his onely sonne:
Doe not lose him, your fortune, and your selfe
For a fraile peece of beauty: shake her off;
And doe some notable thing against her house,
To please your father
The Divell speakes it in thee,
And with this spell I must Conjure him out.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Oh friend you are too violent.

lg.l: Hee's too desperate,
To urge me to an act of such injustice.
Can her faire love, to whom my faith is given,
Be answered with so loud an injury?
Or can my faith so broken yield a sound
Lesse terrible than thunder, to affright
All love and constancy out of the breast
Of every Virgin that shall heare the breach
Of my firme faith?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Be not so passionate.

lg.l: I have no further power to doe an out-rage
Against that Family to whome my heart
Is link'd, then to rip out this troubled heart
The onely ominous cause, indeed, of all.
My over passionate fathers cruelty; and that
(If I must needs doe an injurious Office)
Alone, shall be my act to calme his fury.
Prethee blow o're this passion; thou wert wont
To affect wit, and canst not be a Lover
Truely without it. Love is wit it selfe,
And through a thousand lets will find a way
To his desired end.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Ballet taught you that.

lg.l: Well said, Love will find out the way:
I see thou art comming to thy selfe againe,
Can there no shift, no witty slight be found
(That have been common in all times and ages)
To blind the eyes of a weake-sighted father,
And reconcile these dangerous differences
But by blood-shedding, or outragious deeds,
To make the feud the greater? recollect
Thy selfe good Sam; my house, my purse, my counsell
Shall all be thine, and Wat shall be thy friend.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Let me entreate your friendship.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And me your pardon.

lg.l: So, so, all friends; let's home and there consult
To lay the tempest of thy fathers fury;
Which cannot long be dangerous, 'tis but like
A storme in April, spent in swift extreames,
When straight the Sun shootes forth his cheerefull beames.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: YOu will not assault me in mine owne house? I hope you will not; nor urge me beyond my patience with your borroughing attempts! good sir Hugh Mony-lacks I hope you will not.

lg.l: I hope I mov'd you not, but in faire language sir;
Nor spoke a sillable that might offend you.
I have not us'd the word of loane, or borrowing;
Onely some private conference I requested.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Private conference! a new coyn'd word for borrowing of money; I tell you, your very face, your countenance (though it be gloss'd with Knight-hood) lookes so borrowingly, that the best words you give me are as dreadfull as Stand and deliver, and there I thinke I was w'ye. I am plaine w'ye sir, old Will Striker I.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My father Striker, I am bold to call you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Your father! no, I desire no such neare acquaintaince with you, good sir Hugh Mony-lacks: you are a Knight and a noble gentleman, I am but an Esquire and out of debt; and there I think I was w'ye againe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall be with you anon, when you have tal'kd your selfe out of breath.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I had the honour to be your Worships father in law when time was, that your Knight-hood married and Ladyfied a poore daughter of mine: but yet she had five thousand pounds in her purse if you please to remember it; and as I remember you had then foureteene hundred a yeare: But where is it now? and where is my daughter now? poore abus'd Innocent; your riotousnesse abroad, and her long night watches at home shortned her dayes, and cast her into her grave— And 'twas not long before all your estate was buried too; and there I was w'ye againe I take it: but that could not fetch her againe.

lg.l: No sir, I wish my life might have excus'd
Hers, farre more precious: never had a man
A juster cause to mourne.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Nor mourn'd more justly, it is your onely wearing; you have just none other: nor have had meanes to purchase better any time these seaven yeares as I take it. By which meanes you have got the name of the mourning Knight; and there I am sure I was w'ye.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sir, if you will not be pleas'd to heare my desires to you, let me depart without your derision.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
Even when you please, and whither you please good sir Hugh Mony-lacks: my house shall bee no enchanted Castle to detaine your Knight-errandship from your adventures. I hope
your errand hither was but for your dinner; and so farre forth (and especially at your going forth) you are welcome. Your daughter I doe keepe, and will for her poore mothers sake; (that was my daughter) peace be with her— she shall be no more a trouble to you; nor be your child any longer: I have made her mine; I will adopt her into mine owne name, and make her a Striker; she shall be no more a Mony-lacke, and if shee please me well in matching with a husband, I know what I will doe for her.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Doe you thanke me sir, I assure you you neede not; for I meane so to order her estate, and bind it up in that trust that you shall never finger a farthing on't: am I w'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I cannot chuse but thanke you though in behalfe of my child.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Call her your child agen, or let mee but heare that you suffer her to aske you a bare blessing, ile send her after you upon adventures sir Knight: and who shall give a portion with her then? or what can she hope from a father that groanes under the weight of a Knight-hood for want of meanes to support it?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall finde meanes to live without your trouble hereafter.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You may, you may; you have a wit sir Hugh, and a projective one; what, have you some new project a foot now, to out-goe that of the Hand-barrowes? what call you 'em the Sedams? oh cry you mercy, cry you mercy; I heard you had put in for a share at the Asparagus Garden: or that at least you have a Pension thence; to be their Gather guest and bring 'em custome, and that you play the fly of the new Inne-there; and sip with all companies: am I w'ye there sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may be when you please sir; I can command the best entertainement there for your mony.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
In the meane time sir, I had no mind to begge nor borrow of you, and though you will not give me leave to call you father, nor my daughter my daughter, yet I thought it might become my care to advertise you (that have taken the care of her from me) of a danger that will much afflict you, if it bee not
carefully prevented.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You have an adversary—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: But one that I know, the rascall my neighbour Touchwood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There I am w'ye sir, I am inform'd that his onely sonne is an earnest Suitor to your Daughter: (I must not call her mine)

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That there is a deepe secret love betwixt 'em; and that they have had many private meetings: and a stolne match very likely to be made if you prevent it not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Give me but a peece from you, and if by due examination you find it not so, ile never see your face agen till you send for me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To be rid of you take it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I am gone sir, and yet I thinke i'me w'ye.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Is the Divell become a match-broker? what, who within there: what?
Annabell? what Friswood?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: HEere sir, I am here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Are you so forsooth? but where's your Mistris forsooth?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Listning is good sometimes; I heard their talke, and am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where is your Mrs. I say?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: My Mrs. Annabell, forsooth, my young Mrs?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What other Mrs. hast thou but the Divells Dam her selfe, your old Mrs.? and her I aske not for; good Mrs. Flibber de'Jibb with the French fly-flap o' your coxecombe.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Is the old man mad troe?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I aske for Annabell.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Blesse me! how doe you looke?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where's Annabell I say? fetch her me quickly, least I bast her out of your old Whit-leather hide.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
How youthfull you are growne? she is not farre to fetch sir; you know you commanded her to her chamber, and not to
appeare in sight, till her debauch'd father was gone out o'the house.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And is not he gone now forsooth? why call you her not?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I warrant hee has told you some tale on her. That lewd Knight, now he has undone himselfe by his unthrifty practises, begins to practise the undoing of his daughter too! is it not so forsooth? has he not put some wickednesse into your head to set you against her?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I never knew thee a Witch till now.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; I warrant hee told you that your adversary Touchwoods sonne, and my Mistris Annabell are in love league together.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Marry did he; and I will know the truth.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Dar'st thou laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: No, no; but I laugh at the poore Knights officiousnes, in hope of some great reward for the gullery that I put upon him: ha, ha, ha. Good sir a little patience, and I will tell! you. Ha, ha, ha— 'twas I that devised it for a lye, and told it him in hope that his telling of it to you, would provoke you to beate him out o'the house; for reporting a thing that had no probability or resemblance of a truth in it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Is it but so?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir I have beene your creature this thirty yeares, downe lying and uprising; (as you know) and you should beleeve mee, you had me in my old Mistresses dayes——

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I, thou wast a handsome young wench then; now thou art old.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yet not so wondrous old as to be sung in a Ballet for't, or to have beene able ere Adam wore beard to have crept into Eves bed, as I did into my Mistresses. (Heaven pardon you, as I doe with all my heart.)

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What in thy fooleries now?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nor so old neither but you are content to make a sorry shift with me still; as your abilities will serve you—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Come, come; thou art not old.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Nay that's not it that troubles me: but that I, that serv'd you before your daughter was borne; I meane your daughter that
was mother to this daughter which now you have made your daughter; that I that saw the birth, the marriage, and the death of your daughter; and have had the governance of this her daughter ever since, till now she is marriageable; and have all this while beene as plyant as a twig about you, and as true as the sheath to your steele as we say, that I should now be mistrusted to connive at an il match for her, for whom my chiefest care has bin from the Cradle? there's the unkindnesse.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Enough, enough; Fid. I beleeve there is no such matter.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I thought you had knowne me—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I doe, I doe; I prethee good Fid be quiet, it was a witty tricke of thee to mocke the poore Knight withall: but a poxe on him, he cost me a peece for his newes; there's another for thee: but the best is he hath tyed himselfe by it, never to trouble mee more; I have that into my bargaine.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And you would tye me so too; would you?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Not so Fid, not so: but looke to my Girle, and thus farre marke me. If ever I find that young Touchwood, the sonne of that miscreant, whose hatred I would not lose for all the good neighbor-hood in the Parish; if ever J say, he and your charge doe but looke upon one another, ile turne her and you both out o' doores: there J will be w'ye, looke to't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Agreed sir; agreed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Looke to't J say, J must abroad, my anger is not over yet: I would I could meete my adversary to scold it out; I shall bee sicke else.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: 'Twas well I over-heard 'em, my young lovers had bin spoyl'd else: had not I crost the old angry mans purpose before he had met with the young timerous Virgin, she had confest all; and and all had bin dash'd now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: HOw now Fris. is my Grand-father gone out of doore?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Jf he were as safe out o'the world, it were well for you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Nay say not so good Fris.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Your unlucky father has destroyed all your hopes in Mr.
Sam Touchwood; in discovering your loves (what Divell soever gave him the intelligence) and you must resolve never to see your sweet Sam againe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I must resolve to dye first: oh.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ods pitty! how now! why Mrs. why Annabell, why Mrs. Annabell; looke up, looke up I say, and you shall have him spight of your Grand-father and all his workes: what doe you thinke I am an Infidell, to take Mr. Samuels forty peeces? and a Ronlet of old Muskadine for nothing? come be well, and indeed you shall have him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh Sam, sweet Sam—

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: These love-sicke maides seldome call upon other Saints then their sweet-hearts; looke up I say, your sweet Sam is comming.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ha, where? where is he; why doe you abuse me?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I say he will come presently; looke up I say, forgive me! he comes indeed: my Mr. thought I was a witch, and I now suspect my selfe for one. Oh Mr. Samuel, how came you hither? here he is Mrs. what meane you to come now to undoe her and your selfe too? yet she had dyed and you had not come as you did. Why doe you not looke upon him and be well? get you gone, we are all undone if my Mr. come backe and find you: speake to her quickly, then kisse her and part, you will bee parted for ever else.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How fares my love?

lg.l: Better then when I was in earthly being,
This bosome is a heaven to me; through death
I am arriv'd at blisse, most happily
To be so well reviv'd thou mad'st me dye.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I made you not dye, as you will dye, if you stand pratling till my Mr. returne and take you: for Mr. Samuel, I must tell you Mr. Samuel, he knowes all Mr. Samuel.

lg.l: My father knowes as much, and that's the cause
Of my adventuring hither to instruct you
In a strange practice; here it is in writing, A paper.
'Tis such a secret that I durst not trust
My tongue with the conveyance of't; nor have I
The confidence to heare it read: take it,
And in my absence joyne your best advises,
To give it life and action; 'tis rule
Which (though both hard and grievous to pursue)
Is all that can our hopes in love renew.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What horrible thing must we doe troe? pray let mee see the paper, I hope there is no pistolling nor poisoning in it: though my old Striker come short of the man he was to bee with me, I would be loath to shorten his dayes with the danger of my neck; or making a Bon-fire in Smithfield: pray let me see the paper.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not untill my departure gentle Friswood.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Is there such horrour in it, that you dare not stand the opening of the paper?

lg.l: Consider sweet our love is Feaver sick,
Even desperately to death;
And nothing but a desperate remedy
Is left us: for our bodily health, what sowre
Unsavory loathsome medicines we will take
But to remove an Ague?
What sharpe incisions, searings, and cruell Corsives
Are daily suffer'd, and what limbes dissever'd
To keepe a Gangreene from the vitall parts,
That a dismembred body yet may live!
We in like case must to preserve our love,
(If we dare say we love) adventure life,
Fame, Honour, which are all but Loves attendants
To maintaine it.
I understand you, sweet,
And doe before I read your strong injunction,
Resolve to give it faithfull execution
What ere it be. I ha got courage now,
And (with a constant boldnesse let me tell you)
You dare not lay that on me Ile not beare:
And Love, predominant o're all other passions,
Shall beare me out in't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh you have made me happy.

lg.l: As I live my Master—
Kisse and away; whip quickly through the Garden—
Run you up to your Chamber; ile see you out my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thus let us breath that till we meete againe.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Whoope what d'ee meane?

lg.l: We leave for truce at raysing of the siege,
Our interchanged hearts each others pledge.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Goe fooles, this sets you both but more on edge.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Farewell,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: SWeet wife content thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Yes content my selfe! shall I so? with what, you Iohn Bopeepe? you must be my husband, and I must content my selfe, must I? no sir, 'tis you that must content me, or 'tis your heart must smart for't.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: If you could be content with all that I have, or all that I can doe, and expect no further, I then might hope to pacifie you.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: All has not done it yet you see, nor have you yet found out the way. Five yeares practice one would thinke were sufficient, so long you have had me; and too long it is unlesse I had got a better name by't, to be accounted barren—— oh me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Now 'tis out; zonnes what would you have me doe? where's the defect think you? is it not probable that you may be defective as well as I?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: That I may bee defective! I defie thee, Lubber; I defie thee and all that say so, thou fribling fumbler thou; I would some honest sufficient man might be Judge betwixt us whether I bee defective.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How now, alwaies wrangling?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Defective quoth a—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What's the matter Land-lord?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Doe I looke like a thing defective?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Land-Lady—

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Oh fearefull!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Mrs. Brittle-ware what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: You shall be Judge Sir Hugh, whether I bee defective; you have lyen here Sir Hugh these three yeares, have beene our constant lodger off and on as wee say; and can you thinke mee defective?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: You will not be impudent?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good Mr. Brittle-ware what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The matter is sir she will be content with nothing.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The best wife i'the world! and if you cannot afford her that to content her, you are a most hard-harted husband.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: What nothing? would you wish him to afford mee nothing to content me? I must have something to content me; and something he must find me, or I will make him looke out for't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come, come, I know the quarrell; and I know you will never get a child by falling out.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Nor any way else so long as hee is such a jealous beast as hee is.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Oh you must leave your jealousie Mr. Brittleware; that's a maine hindrance

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I am not jealous I.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Not, and stare like a mad Oxe upon every man that lookes upon me?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Fye upon him, is he such a beast, to be jealous of his owne wife? if every man were so, it would spoyle the getting of some children in a yeare.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: And denies me all things that I have a mind to.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The best is, the losse of your longings will not hurt you; unlesse you were with child.

lg.l: I must have my longings first; I am not every woman I,
I must have my longings before I can be with child I.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: You must not long for every strange thing you see or heare of then.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: As true as I live he fribles with mee sir Hugh; I doe but now long for two or three idle things scarce worth the speaking of; and doe you thinke he will grant me one of 'em?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What may they be? he shall grant 'em.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: One of my longings is to have a couple of lusty able bodied men, to take me up, one before and another behind, as the new fashion is, and carry mee in a Man-litter into the great bed at Ware.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There's one, and will you deny her this to hinder a child getting?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Then I doe long to see the new ship, and to be on the top of Pauls Steeple when it is new built, but that must not bee yet; nor am I so unreasonable but I can stay the time: in the meane time I long to see a play, and above all playes, The Knight of the burning— whatdee' call't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The Knight of the burning Pestle.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Pestle is it? I thought of another thing, but I would faine see it. They say there's a Grocers boy kills a Gyant in it, and another little boy that does a Citizens wife thy daintielist—— but I would faine see their best Actor doe me; I would so put him too't, they should find another thing in handling of mee I warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Heyday! so last frost she long'd to ride on one of the Dromedaries over the Thames, when great men were pleas'd to goe over it a foote.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, shall I make a convenient motion for you both?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Quickely sweet sir Hugh, I long for that before you name it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Have you this Spring eaten any Asparagus yet?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why is that good for a woman that longs to bee with Child?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Of all the Plants, hearbes, rootes, or fruits that grow, it is the most provocative, operative and effective.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
All your best (especially your moderne) Herballists conclude, that your Asparagus is the onely sweet stirrer that the
earth sends forth, beyond your wild Carrets, Corne-flag, or Gladiall. Your roots of Standergrasse, or of Satyrion boyld in Goates milke are held good; your Clary or Horminum in divers wayes good, and Dill (especially boyld in Oyle) is also good: but none of these, nor Saffron boyld in wine, your Nuts of Artichoakes, Rocket, or seeds of Ash-tree (which wee call the Kite keyes) nor thousand such, though all are good, may stand up for perfection with Asparagus.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Doe you say so sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I have it from the opinion of most learned Doctors, rare Physitians, and one that dares call himselfe so.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: What Doctor is he, a foole on horse-backe?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Doctor Thou-Lord, you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Yes, we know Doctor Thou-Lord, though he knowes none but Lords and Ladies, or their companions. And a fine conceited Doctor he is, and as humorous I warrant yee; and will Thou and Thee the best Lords that dares be acquainted with him: calls Knights, Iacke, Will, and Tom familiarly; and great Ladies, Gills, and Sluts too, and they crosse him. And for his opinion sake, and your good report sir Hugh, I will have Sparagus every meale all the yeare long, or ile make all fly for't; and doe you looke to't Fribble, for it will bee for your comodity as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And sure it is a rare commodity when a Knight is become a Broker for to cry it up so.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: And let me have some presently for my next meale, or you cannot imagine how sicke I will be.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But mistake not me, nor the commodity we speake of Mrs. Brittle-ware; where would you have it? here in our owne house? fye! the vertue of it is mortified, if it passe the threshold from the ground it growes on. No, you must thither, to the Garden of delight, where you may have it drest and eaten in the due kind; and there it is so provocative, and so quicke in the hot operation, that none dare eate it, but those that carry their coolers with 'em, presently to delay, or take off the delightfull fury it fills 'em with.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Is there conveniency for that too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; the house affords you as convenient Couches to retyre to, as the garden has beds for the precious plants to
grow in: that makes the place a pallace of pleasure, and daily resorted and fill'd with Lords and Knights, and their Ladies; Gentlemen and gallants with their Mistresses—

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: But doe not honest men goe thither with their wives too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: None other; some to their owne costs, and some at other mens.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why doe we not goe then? or what stay we for, can you tell fumbler?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Nay Mrs. Brittle-ware, not so suddenly; towards the evening will be the fittest season of the day: meane while goe in and fit your selfe for the walke, your husband and I are first for an other busines.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Noble Knight I thanke you, I hope my next longing shall be to bespeake you for a God-father.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall not long long for that.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I take your noble word.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: She's gone, and now sir Hugh let me tell you, you have not dealt well with me, to put this fagary into her foolish fancy.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Wilt thou be an Asse now? doe not I know how to fetch it out on her againe think'st thou? she shall not goe, and yet be contented too.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I you tell me so

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why thou wilt not be jealous of me now, that has laine in thy house these three yeares, wilt thou? nor thinke me so foolish to provoke thee with an injury; that know'st mee and my wayes so well.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I know something by your worship worth the price of a new Pillory.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why so then; and wil I wrong thee Iack think'st thou, ha? no nor mistrust thee neither: for though thou art a jealous coxcomb over thy wife, and she a touchy thing under thee, yet thou and I Iacke have bin alwaies confident of each other, and have wrought friendly and closely together, as ever Subtle and his Lungs did; and shar'd the profit betwixt us, han't we Iacke: ha?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I thinke we have; and that you have some new device, some stratagem in hand now. Uds me, I now remember, is the party come to towne?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes; and my Springe has seaz'd him upon the way: and
here I expect him instantly.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And will he be made a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That's his ambition Iacke; and though you now keepe a China-shop, and deale in brittle commodities (pots, glasses, Purslane Dishes, and more trinkets then an Antiquaries study is furnished withal) you must not forget your old trade of Barber Surgeon, 'tis that must sted us now in our new project.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I warrant you, is he a trim youth?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: We must make him one Iacke, 'tis such a squab as thou never sawest; such a lumpe, we may make what we will of him.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Then sure we will make mony of him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well said Iacke, Springe has writ mee here his full description.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: SLid hee's come already: now Mr. Springe?

sp.speaker: Spri.
sp.p: I come to present a gentleman to you sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How a gentleman? will you abuse me?

sp.speaker: Spri.
sp.p: He findes your defect already; but be bold sir, he desires to be a Gentleman sir; and (tho' he be but course mettall, yet) he has that about him which with your helpe may quickly make him a cleare Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I have foure hundred pounds sir; and I brought it up to towne on purpose to make my selfe a cleare gentleman of it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It was well brought up; it appeares also that you have had some breeding, though but a Yeomans sonne.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I have a little learning sir, and a little wit, though last night I met with some upon the way at Hammer-Smith that had more: yet I had enough to perceive I was cheated of a matter of seaven pound (almost all the odde mony I had about me) at my Card afore thy Card; a pox take the whole packe on 'em. Sdaggers if ever man that had but a mind to be a Gentleman was so noddy poopt! oh how I could chafe to thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Oh but you must not, it becomes not the temper of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: So you told me; then I thanke you friend.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Your small acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I have had more acquaintance where I have found lesse love, and I thanke you agen good small acquaintance: you told me indeed it became not a gentleman to crie for losing his mony; and I told you then, that I should, or would be a gentleman: Whereupon Small acquaintance (because I was resolv'd to play no more) you advis'd me to give over; and you told me you would upon our comming to the City, here bring mee to a Knight, that was a Gentleman-maker, whom I conceive this to be, and here am I, and here's my foure hundred pound, which my man has here drawne up to Towne, and here I meane to quarter it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: But I will see what penniworths you bargaine for first, by your Masterships leave.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Drawne and quarter'd! you have a wit Sir, I find that already.

sp.speaker: Hoy,
sp.p: Yes sir, I have a downe right Country wit, and was counted a pretty sparke at home. Did you never heare of little Tim of Tanton? But I now meane to have a finicall City wit, and a superfinicall Court wit too, before I see mine Vncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And be able to jest and jeere among men of judgment: I have a many small jests, petty Johns, as I call 'hem: But I will have a clubbing wit, and a drinking wit; and be able to hold play with the great Poets I: and with dry jests to maule the mallipart'st lesser ones (that hold themselves better than the biggest) out o'the pit of wit I, before I see mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may have all sir, if you quarter your foure hundred pound discreetly: but who is your uncle I pray?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: For that you shall pardon me, till I am a Gentleman: But I assure you he is a great gentleman in the City here; and I neither must nor dare see him, till I am one at least: and I will tell you presently how I meane to quarter my money.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: They'll quarter that and you too, if I zee not the better to the matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Dost thou know the uncle he speaks of?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No, nor cannot learne who it is for my life.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Some great man sure that's asham'd of his kindred: perhaps some Suburbe Justice, that sits o'the skirts o'the City, and lives by't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well said Iack.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Look you sir, thus had I cast it: Small acquaintance pray doe you note it too: I love your advice, that at first sight of mee (which was but last night) could relieve me from Cheaters.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: From some of his owne companions to cheate, you more himselfe.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The first hundred pound to be for the making of mee a gentleman: the second hundred shall be for apparell.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He speaks halfe like a gentleman already.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Right, there's halfe dispos'd of.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The third hundred Ile spend in pleasure: harke Small acquaintance, we'll have wenches.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What wants he of a gentleman, and goe no further, but save the last hundred.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Oh Small acquaintance, that must walke too: but all for profit to support my gentility hereafter.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I will be cheated of it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Nor in grosse, but by retaile, to trye mens severall wits, and so learne to shift for my selfe in time and need be.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Doe you heare this?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Theres a plot now!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I protest I admire him: J never found like Craft in a Yeomans sonne before.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: No words on't J beseech you sir; nor name that foolish word Yeomans sonne any more: J came to change my Coppy, and write Gentleman: and to goe the nighest way to worke, my Small acquaintance here tells me, to goe by the Heralds is the farthest way about.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sir, we will take the speediest course for you that may be possible.

lg.l: The season of the yeare serves most aptly too,
Both for purging and bleeding:
Give your name into this booke sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Timothy Hoyden, sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Timothy Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But must J bleed sir?

lg.l: Yes, you must bleed: your fathers blood must out,
He was but a yeoman, was he?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: As ranck a Clowne, none disprais'd, as any in Sommerset shire.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: His foule ranke blood of Bacon and Pease-porridge must out of you to the last dram.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You will leave me none in my body then, I shall bleed to death, and you go that way to worke.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Feare nothing sir: your blood shalbe taken out by degrees, and your veines replenish'd with pure blood still, as you loose the puddle.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: How must that be done?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I that ich I would heare.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I commend you that you seeke reason: it must bee done by meats and drinkes of costly price; Muscadell caudels, jellies, and cock-broaths. You shall eate nothing but Shrimpe porridge for a fortnight; and now and then a Phesants egge soopt with a Peacocks feather. I that must be the dyet.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Delicate!

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: This stands to reason indeed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Then at your going abroad, the first ayre you take shalbe of the Asparagus Garden, and you shall feed plentifully of that.

sp.speaker: Hoy
sp.p: Of the ayre do you meane?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No of th'Asparagus. And that with a Concoction of Goates milke, shall set you an end, and your blood as high as any Gentlemans lineally descended from the loyns of King Cadwalader.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Excellent, I like all excellently well, but this bleeding. I could never endure the sight of blood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That shewes the malignant basenesse of your fathers blood within you.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I was bewitch'd I thinke before I was begot, to have a Clowne to my father: yet sit my mother said shee was a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Said? What will not Women say?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
Nay, small acquaintance, she profest it upon her Death-bed to the Curate and divers others, that she was sister to a Gentleman here in this City; and commanded mee in her Will, and uppon her blessing, first to make my selfe a Gentleman of good fashion,
and then to goe to the gentleman my uncle.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I must not, nor I wo'not tell you that, till I am a gentleman my selfe: would you ha' me wrong the will o' the dead? Small acquaintance, I will rather dye a Clowne as I am first.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Be content sir; here's halfe a labour sav'd; you shall bleed but o' one side: the Fathers side onely.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The Mother vaine shall not be prickt.

lg.l: I thanke you sir:
I wou'd 'twere done once.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But when this is done, and your new blood infused into you, you shall most easily learne the manners and behaviour.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The Look, the garbe, the congee—

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And all the Complements of an absolute gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O brave!

lg.l: For which you shall have best instructions;
You'le runne a chargeable course in't, that Ile tell you:
And may yet if you please retaine your money;
Crosse your mothers will and dye a Clowne.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: By no meanes sir.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I begin to beleeve honestly of the Knight.

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.p: Doe you note this skin of his here?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Skin, 'tis a hide sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat thicke and foule indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: He must have a bath, and that will be more charge.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Tis pitty he should be flead.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I thanke you small acquaintance; pray let me have a bath, what ere it cost me, rather than flea me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sir, this house shall be your lodging, and this the Mr. of it, an excellent Chyrurgeon, and expert in these affaires, shall be your attendant.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: My man may attend me too, may he not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, by all meanes, and see the laying out of your money.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I like that best: sure they are honest men.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Is that your man? what does he weare a Coulter by his side?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p:
No sir, my name is Coulter; I my selfe am a Coulter.
and this is but my Hanger on, as I am my Masters.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Thou maist make a Country gentleman in time, I see that by thy wit.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: All my friends will be glad on't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, Ile lead you the way.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: BVt how can you assure me gentlemen that this is true?

lg.l: We saw't not acted sir, nor had reported it,
But on those termes of honour you have sworne to;
In which you are engaged first to forgive
Your sonne: then never to reveale to friend,
Or foe, the knowledge of the fact.
You cannot now but receive
Your sonne into your favour, that did urge him
To doe some outrage, some villanous shame or mischiefe
Vpon that Family as he would shunne your curse.
This is a mischiefe with a witnesse to it:
He has done it home it seems.
Sir, can a sonne
Doe his fathers will too fully?
You may be pleas'd to call him. Exit Wat.
I would now put on anger, but I feare
My inward joy's too great, to be dissembled:
Now for a rigid brow that might enable
A man to stand competitor for the seate
Of austere justice— Are you come to boast Enter Sam, Wat.
The bravery of your fact, with a dissembled
Shew of obedience; as if you had merited
Forgivenesse and a blessing; when my shame
For thy lewd action makes me turne and hide
My face— for feare my laughter be descry'd.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Pray turne not from him sir.

lg.l: I have heard sir of your workmanship; but may
A man receive it on your word for truth?
It is too true, unlesse you please in mercy
To pardon, and preserve me from the rigour
Of Justice, and the sharper censure
That I shall suffer in all good opinion.
I meane you shall out o'the noyse on't presently:
So— there's a hundred peeces, get you gone;
Provide you for a journey into France,
Beare your selfe well, and looke you come not home
A verier Coxecombe than you went abroad:
Pray weare no falling bands and cuffes above
The price of suits and cloaks, least you become
The better halfe undone in about at Buffets.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I hope you shall heare well of me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pray blesse me sir.

lg.l: My blessing be upon thee,
Goe get thee gone, my tendernesse will shew
It selfe too womanish else.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Goodnesse of nature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We'll helpe to set you forward.

lg.l: Thank yee gentlemen:
Be but my sonne, thou shalt not want a father,
Though somebody must seeke one: ha, ha, ha—
Ide give another hundred Peeces now
With all my heart, that I might be untongue-ty'd,
And triumph o're my adversary now,
And dash this businesse in his angry teeth:
Strike Strikers teeth out with his owne abuse:
Perhaps he knows't already, if he does;
I may take notice, and make bold to jeere him:
This is his usuall walke.
I was too blame
To give it so much credit at the first,
As to be troubled at it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: 'Tis the Rascall.

lg.l: That he, the sonne of my despight and scorne,
Should gaine of Fate a lot to see my Neece,
Much lesse a face to aske her for his wife.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Perhaps he's casting of his will.

lg.l: Yet the vexation that I was but told so,
Lyes gnawing in my stomacke, that untill
I vomit it upon that Dung-hill wretch;
I cannot eate nor sleepe to doe me good.
And I thanke Chance he's here.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He comes, and so have at him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, humh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And ha, ha, ha to thee old puppy.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, how dar'st thou keepe a sonne that dares but looke upon my Neece? there I am we'yee sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sirrah, and sirrah to thy wither'd jawes, and down that wrinkled throat of thine: how dar'st thou think a sonne of mine dares for displeasing me, look but with foule contempt upon thy loathed issue?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Impudent villaine, I have heard he has seene her.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Has he but seene her? ha, ha, ha, I feare I shall out with it: I would not be forsworne: Ile keep't in if I can.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yes Malipert Jack, I have heard that he has seene her, but better hadst thou pist him gainst the wall, then hee presume to love her: and there I am we'yee sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hast thou but heard he has seene her: I tell thee thou old booby thou; if he had seen, felt, heard, and understood her: nay had he got her with child, and then left her, he were my sonne, and I would cherish him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Darst thou speak so, thou old Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou dost not heare me say it is so, though J could wish it were with all my heart, because I thinke it would breake thine.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hugh, hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I hope I shall keepe it within the compasse of mine oath; yet there was a touch for him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Oh thou hel-bred Rascall thou; hugh, hugh,

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, so, up with it, Lungs, Lights, Liver, and all: choake up in a churles name.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I have put him into these fits forty times at least, and not without hope it will thratle him at last—— if you do break a gut, or a rib or two, with straining, a rope will be your onely remedy: and so I leave you: by the way you have not heard mee say that I know any thing by your Neece: But what I know Ile keep to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And hang thy selfe, I care not what thou know'st, yet thus farre take me we'yee sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not a step, unlesse I were sure I were going to the devill, huh, huh: no sir, you shall not trip me: you shall not fetch it out of me: tush, my sonne's my sonne, and keep your neece to yourselfe, huh, and if she has any thing of his you may keep that too huh; and so choake up againe with all my heart, and much good doe it you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh— hum! so he's gon, the villain's gone in hope that he has kild me, when my comfort is he has recover'd mee:

lg.l: I was heart-sicke with a conceit which lay so mingled with my
Fleagme that I had perished, if I had not broke it, and made me
spit it out; hemh, 'tis gone, and ile home merrily.
I would not that he should know the good he has done me
For halfe my estate; nor would I be at peace with him
To save it all: His malice works upon me,
Past all the drugs and all the Doctors Counsells,
That ere I cop'd with: he has beene my vexation
These thirty yeares; nor have I had another
Ere since my wife dy'd; if the Rascall knew't,
He would be friends, and I were instantly
But a dead man, I could not get another
To anger me so handsomly.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: YOu are welcome home sir.

lg.l: And merrily too Fid. Hemh light at heart,
I met with my Physitian, Dog-leech, Touchwood;
And clear'd my stomacke, and now I am light at heart.
And thou shalt heare on't Fid anon perhaps.
You are the better able then to heare
And beare what I must tell you.
Where's my Neece?
How does she, ha?
As well as a young woman
In her case may doe sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ha! how's that?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Twill out, and I as fit to tell't you as another.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Out with it then.

lg.l: Tis true, I fac'd you downe there was no league
Betweene young Touch-wood, and your Neece, in hope
To turne her heart from him before the knowledge
Of any thing that past should be a griefe to you:
But since I have discover'd tis too late;
And she can be fit bride for no man else.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: He has not laine with her, has he?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You speake as just as Gormans lips.

lg.l: I hope he has not lipt her so:
Prethee what canst thou meane?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, if you thinke
The knowledge of a truth of this sad nature

May prejudice your health, by drawing a Cholericke fit into you, you were best to send for your Physitian, your dog-leech Touchwood, as you cal'd him, to breake your bed of Fleagme, by laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What dost thou meane now, I have asked thee twice.

lg.l: I say young Touch-wood has touch'd, and clap'd your neece;
And (which is worse) with scorne and foule disdaine
Has left and quite forsaken; and is gone:
(They say) sent by his father to travaile.
Twas this the villaine hammer'd on to day,
When he spoke mystically, doubtfull words,
Reflecting on this mischievous sence: Hell, hell, hell.
Twere good you would forsake the thought of hell sir,
And thinke upon some timely course to save
Her credit, and the honour of your house by marriage.
You counsell very well;
But were you privy in their loves affaire?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Indeed I knew too much on't: think of a course good sir.

lg.l: I know no course for her and you but one,
Young whore and bawd, and that is instantly
To pack you out of doores to seek your living,
And there I will be we'yee.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir that you must not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sprecious dost thou must me in mine owne house?

lg.l: In your owne house sir, kill us if you please,
And take the sinne upon you; but out of it
You must not dare to thrust us with your shame:
Which I will so divulge, as you shall finde
Your house to be no sanctuary for your selfe;
And there ile be with you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: This is lusty.

lg.l: Consider wisely that I know you sir,
And can make foule relation of some passages
That you will shame to heare.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

lg.l: Remember sir, neare thirty yeares agoe,
You had a sister, whose great marriage portion
Was in your hands: good gentlewoman, she
Vnfortunately loving a false Squire,
Just as your Neece hath now, did get a clap:
You know sir what I meane.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You'll hold your peace?

lg.l: Ile speake it though I dye for't; better here
Than in a worse place: So clapt I say she was,
I know not yet by whom you doe, and beare
An inward grudge against some body to this houre for't.
But to my story, good gentlewoman she
Was by your most unbrotherly cruell usage
Thrust out a doores, as now you threaten us:
And miserably big-bellied as she was
Leaving her most unjustly detain'd her portion
In your false hands, forsooke you and the towne,
To flie the aire, where her disgrace was spread:
Some jewells and some gold she had conceal'd:
But to what part o'th' world shee took we know not,
Nor did you ever care, but wisht her out on't,
By any desperate end, after her flight
From portion, blood and name; and so perhaps
Immediately she was: for which, this judgement
Is justly falne upon you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yet hold thy peace.

lg.l: Neither by threats, nor bribes, nor all perswasion,
Untill you take your Neece into your care:
What will the world say when it heares this story
Of your owne naturall sister, and your cruelty,
When you shall second it with your Neeces shame?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I never was so mated, so astonished.

lg.l: Nay, more than this, old Striker, ile impeach
You for foule incontinence; and shaking your
Old Bullion Tronkes over my Trucklebed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Thou art not desperate! wilt thou shame thy selfe?

lg.l: I value neither shame, nor name, nor fame;
And wealth I have none to lose; you have enough
To pay for all I take it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Oh I am sicke.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Be of good cheere, ile send for your Physitian.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sicke, sicke at heart; let me be had to bed.

lg.l: I hope I have laid the heat of his severity,
So sometimes great offences passe for none,
When severe Iudges dare not heare their owne.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Gardner, and Martha his wife.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p:
PRay lets agree upon't good wife, you are my wife I take it, and I should have the command, yet I entreate,
and am content you see.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And so would any man I thinke that has such a help and commings in by his wife as you have: tis not your durty Sparagus, your Artichoaks, your Carpes, your Tulips, your Strawberries, can bring you in five hundred pound a yeare, if my helping hand, and braine too were not in the businesse?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Let us agree upon't: and two or three yeares toyle more, while our trade is in request and fashion, will make us purchasers. I had once a hope to have bought this Mannor of Marshland for the resemblance it has to the Low Country soyle you came from, to ha' made you a Banke-side Lady. Wee may in time be somewhat. But what did you take yesterday Mat in all, what had you, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Poore pidling doings; some foure and twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: What did the rich old Merchant spend upon the poore young gentlemans wife in the yellow bed-chamber?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But eight and twenty shillings, and kept the roome almost two houres, I had no more of him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: And what the Knight with the broken Citizens wife (that goes so Lady like) in the blew bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Almost foure pound.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: That was pretty well for two.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But her husband, and a couple of serving-men had a dish of Sparagus, and three bottles of wine, besides the broken meate into one o'the Arbors.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Every thing would live Mat: but here will be great Courtiers and Ladyes to day you say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes they sent last night to bespeake a ten pound dinner, but I halfe feare their comming will keep out some of our more constant, and more profitable customers.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Twill make them the more eager to come another time then Mat. Ha' they paid their reckoning in the Parlour?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes, but hutchingly, and are now going away.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O here they are going.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I protest Mr. Gardner your wife is too deare: Sixteene shillings for a dish of Sparagus, two bottles of wine, and a little Sugar, I wonder how you can reckon it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That was your reckoning in all sir; wee make no account of particulars, but all to Mall, as they doe in the Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Your Dutch account Mrs. is too high for us to trouble you any more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That's as you please sir, a faire day after you:
Who would be troubled with such pinching guests?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: I, tis good to misreckon such to be rid of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: They are ee'n as welcome as the Knight that comes hither alone alwayes, and walkes about the garden here halfe a day together, to feed upon Ladyes lookes, as they passe to and fro; the peeping Knight, whát doe you call him?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O Sir Arnold Cautious.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You may call him Cautious, I never saw five shillings of his money yet.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: No, he comes but to feed his eye, as you say, with leering at good faces, and peeping at pretty insteps.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Hugh-Money-lacke, our gather-guest as we call him, sends us no such dull customers: O that good Gentleman I never did any taverne, Inne, or new Ordinary give tribute to a more deserving gentleman— oh here come gallants.

div.head: Act 3. Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Gilbert, Wat, and Sam (disguis'd) to them.
div.p: Three, and ne're a woman! strange! these are not the Courtiers wee look for.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: This is his daily haunt: I warrant thee we find him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And it shall take, ne're feare it Sam.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: By your leave Mr. and Mrs. or rather Lord and Lady of the new plantation here.

sp.speaker: Wat
sp.p: Nay Prince and Princesse of the Province of Asparagus.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Island of two Acres here, more profitable than twice two thousand in the Fens, till the drainers have done there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are pleasant gentlemen: what is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Saw you Sir Arnold Cautious here to day?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Ha' you a roome i' your house for us?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Have you any more company to come to you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, we expect some gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Gentlemen did you say?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yes indeed gentlemen, no gentlewomen I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Intruth sir all the roomes within are gone.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What they are not gone abroad, are they?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are alwayes pleasant sir: I meane they are all taken up.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: There are some taken up in 'hem, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Still you are pleasant sir: they are indeed bespoken for great Courtiers, and Ladyes that are to dine here.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: If you will bestow your selves in the garden, and make choise of your Arbour: you shall have the best cheer the house can afford yee, and you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Be it so then; lets walke about gentlemen. Pray send us some wine.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And a dish of your Sparagus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You shall have it gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Did you note the wit o'the woman?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I, because we had no wenches we must have no chamber-roome, for feare she disappoynt some that may bring 'hem.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Shee spake of great Courtiers and Ladyes that are to come.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Some good stuffe perhaps.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Why I assure you, right noble, and right vertuous persons, and of both sexes doe frequent the place.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And I assure you, as ignoble and vicious doe pester it too much; and these that respect profit meerely have not the wit, and lesse the vertue to distinguish betwixt the best and the worst, but by their purses.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Tis enough for them to weed their garden, not their guests: O here comes our collation.

div.head: Act 3. Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter two boyes, they cover a Table, two bottles of wine, Dishes of Sugar, and a dish of Sparagus.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: ANd what's the price of this feast boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Plaist ill Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What art thou a French-man?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, I tooke you for one sir, to bargaine for your meate before you eate it, that is not the generous English fashion, you shall know anon sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Goe get you gone with your wit, and tell your prodigall fooles so.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Goe, we'll call when we want attendance.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sam you are too sad; let not your disguise alter you with us: Come here's a health to the Hans in Kelder, and the mother of the boy, if it prove so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ile pledge it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We want Sir Hugh Mony-lacke here to discourse the vertues of this precious plant Asparagus, and what wonders it hath wrought in Burgundy, Almaino, Italy, and Languedoc before the herborists had found the skill to plant it here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What's he to whom wee seeke?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Who mine Vncle, Sir Arnold Cautious; he'll come, ne're doubt him; he seldom misses a day to pry and piere upon the beauties that come to walke here.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Tis such a Knightling, Ile but give yee his Character, and and he comes I warrant thee; he is an infinite admirer of beauty, and dares not touch a woman: he is aged about fifty, and a batchelour: he defies wed locke, because he thinkes there is not a maiden-head- in any marriagable beauty to be found among Women.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yet you say he is an admirer and hunter after the sight of beauty.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He gets a crick in his neck oft-times with squinting up at windowes and Belconies; and as he walkes the streets, he peepes on both sides at faire breasts and faces, as he were seeking Birds-nests; and followes pretty feet and insteps like a hare tracker.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: This is still mine Vncle.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And when he sees a Coach of Ladies about to alight, hee makes a stand, in hope to see a delicate legge slip through a lac'd smocke, which if he chance to discover he drivells.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Well, how your plot may hold to my purpose I cannot see: he is the unlikeliest man to have a wench put upon that you can mention.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I grant the attempt is hard, but the higher will be the atchievement: trust my experience Sam: for as in every instrument are all tunes to him that has the skill to find out the stops, so in every man there are all humours to him that can find their faussets, and draw 'hem out to his purpose.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Feare not the plot, as we have cast it, nor the performance in the Comedy, though against mine owne Naturall Vncle.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Thy unnaturall Vuncle thou would'st say; hee ne're did thee good in's life: Act but thine owne part, and be not out Sam, and feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He's somewhat too yong to act a rorer: but what lads have we seene passe for souldiers?

div.head: Act 3. Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter three Courtiers and Ladies: Cautious aloofe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O here come the great guests.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And these are noble ones indeed; these are Courtiers Clinquant, and no counterfeit stuffe upon 'hem: I know 'hem all, every Lady with her owne husband too: what a vertuous 'honest age is this: and see if thine Vncle bee not at his old game, bopeepe i'the taile of 'hem. Hee shall follow 'hem no further: Sir Arnold Cautious, Noble Knight you are well encounter'd.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Good Master Gold wyer, doe you know these Ladies; or be they Ladyes, ha?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yes, and noble ones, the three Graces of the Court, the Lady Stately, the Lady Handsome, and the Lady peerelesse, doe not you know 'hem?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No not I.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How the slave twitters; you look not up at greatnes, you mind too much the worldly things that are beneath you: if you had such a Lady under you, (of your owne I meane) you would mind her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Oh fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Looke no more after 'hem, they are gone: besides they are vertuous, and too too great for you: when will you get a convenient wife of your owne, to work out the dry itch of a stale Batchelour?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Goe, goe, you are a wag, I itch not that way.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you goe this way with me then, and heare what I wil say to you?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: With all my heart, I am free from businesse.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have a Nephew, whose sister I marryed, a vertuous wife she is, and I love him the better for't; he is a younger brother, and borne to no great fortune: now you are very rich, a Batchelour, and therefore I thinke child lesse—

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Introth Mr. Gold-wyer you must pardon mee, I may not stay with you: I had almost forgot a most important businesse.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ee'n now he had none.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay good Sir Arnold Cautious, you know not what Ile say.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say he is an unthrift, a Squanderer, and must not expect supplyes from me.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He does not, shall not, not to the value of a token: pray stay, and heare me sir; tis no ill ayre to stay in.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I with all my heart good Mr. Gold-wyer; I like the aire well, and your motion hitherto.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you be pleas'd to doe your kinsman the favour to further him in a match; I mean an honest lawfull marriage match— but with your countenance, and a good word at most.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: The most unthankfull office in the world: pray use some other friend in't: indeed I stay too long.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Heare but who it is that he loves, how likely he is to obtaine, what abundant profit the match may bring him, and the desperate undoing danger he falls into if he be not matched, and then doe your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Why what new danger is he towards, more than the old
ill company he was wont to keep?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Oh sir, he is now in league with a companion more dreadfull than 'hem all, a fellow that is in part a Poet, and in part a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Bounce, bounce.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have hit upon his name: his name is Bounce, do you know him sir?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Not I, nor desire acquaintance with either of his qualities.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He is a gentleman sir, that has been upon some unfortunate late services, that have not answer'd his merit.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And now he is come home to right himselfe, by writing his owne meritorious acts, is he?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Good introth, I wish you would see 'hem, to come over 'hem with a jeere or two; I know you are good at it: They are in an Arbour here close by, drinking to their Muses, and glorifying one another for eithers excellency in the art most Poetically.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Glorifie doe you say? I have heard Poets the most envious detractors of one another of all Creatures, next to the very Beggers.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Abroad perhaps and asunder, but together there's no such amity: You never saw 'hem drinke; pray see 'hem sir, it may take your Nephew off of his Ningle, who hath infected him with Poetry already: and twenty to one, if he faile in the match, which I was about to mention; he will winne him away to the wars too, and then he may be lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Good Mr. Gold-wyer goe you to your company, I am not a man of reckoning amongst such; besides, I seldome drink betwixt meales.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: At his owne cost he meanes.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I commend your temper: you shall not bee in the reckoning; but I beseech you let me prevaile with you: See, wee are upon hem: save you Gentlemen: I have brought you a noble friend, your uncle; I know he is welcome to you brother Wat; and you I am sure will make him so Mr. Bounce: when you shall heare he is an admirer of Poetry and warre.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Even a farre off I assure yee: I never durst approach near
the fury of either of the fiery qualities.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It is your modesty, not feare that keeps you at distance I imagine.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Poets may imagine any thing: imagination is their wealth, some of 'hem would be but poore else: are you turn'd Poet Nephew?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For my private recreation sir.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What by writing Verses to win some Mistresses to your private recreation: meane you so?

lg.l: You dare not sir blaspheme the vertuous use
Of sacred Poetry, nor the fame traduce
Of Poets, who not alone immortall be,
But can give others immortality.
Poets that can men into stars translate,
And hurle men downe under the feete of Fate:
Twas not Achilles sword, but Homers pen,
That made brave Hector dye the best of men:
And if that powerfull Homer likewise wou'd,
Hellen had beene a hagge, and Troy had stood.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Well said Poet, thou tumblest out old ends as well as the best of 'hem.

lg.l: Poets they are the life and death of things,
Queens give them honour, for the greatest Kings
Have bin their subjects.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Enough, enough; you are the first good Poet that e're I saw weare so good a Countenance: leave it, I would not have a gentleman meddle with Poetry for spoyling of his face: you seldome see a Poet look out at a good Visnomy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes, and that it is a Poeticall Policy, where the face is naturally good without spot or blemish, to deface it by drinking, or wenching, to get a name by't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A death deserving scandall.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

div.stage: They scuffle, and Wat throwes. Sam, and offers to stab him. Gil. holds his Dagger.

lg.l: Thy malice, and thy ignorance
Have doom'd thee.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Gentlemen what meane yee?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: My blood must not endure it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have wrong'd us all, and me the most.

lg.l: The wrong is chiefely mine; yet you adde to it
By hindring my just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ile find a time to right you, or my selfe.

lg.l: My next sight of thee is thy death:
I feare you are hurt sir; are you, pray sir tell me?
Let me first admire thy goodnesse and thy pitty:
My owne true naturall Nephew.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now it workes.

lg.l: I now consider, and will answer thee
In a full measure of true gratitude.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But good sir are you not hurt? if you bleed, I bleed with you.

lg.l: Oh sincere Nephew, good boy I am not hurt,
Nor can I thinke of hurt, my thoughts are bent
Upon thy good; you were speaking of a choyse sir,
My Nephew would be matcht to, let me know the party.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you sir stand his friend?

lg.l: Let me but know the party and her friend,
And instantly about it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He is catch'd.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How am I bound to you!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nephew I am yet bound to thee, and shall not rest till I am dis-ingag'd by doing this office for thee: what is she, let me know?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, as we walk you shall know all: ile pay the reckoning within as we passe.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: But by the way Nephew, I must bind you from Poetry.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For a Wife you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Poetry, though it be of a quite contrary nature, is as pretty a jewell as plaine dealing, but they that use it forget the Proverb.

lg.l: COme Madams, now if you please after your garden Feast,
To exercise your numerous feet, and tread
A curious knot upon this grassie square;
You shall fresh vigour adde unto the spring,
And double the encrease, sweetnesse and beauty
Of every plant and flower throughout the garden.
If I thought so my Lord, we would not doe
Such precious worke for nothing; we would be
Much better huswifes, and compound for shares
O'th' gardners profit.
Or at least hedge in
Our Sparagus dinner reckoning.
I commend your worldly providence:
