Madam, such good Ladies will never dance
Away their husbands Lands.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: But Madams will yee dance?

lg.l: Not to improve the garden good my Lord,
A little for digestion if you please.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: Musicke, play.

lg.l: You have done Nobly Ladyes, and much honour'd
This peece of earth here, with your gracefull footing.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: By your faire imitation, good my Lords.

lg.l: May the example of our harmlesse mirth
And Civill recreation purge the place
Of all foule purposes.
Tis an honest wish:
But wishes weed no gardens; hither come
Some wicked ones they say.
We seek not to abridge their priviledge;
Nor can their ill hurt us; we are safe.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: But let us walke, the time of day calls hence.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: YOu are now welcome to th' Asparagus Garden Land-lady.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I have beene long a comming for all my longings: but now I hope I shall have my belly full on't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That you shall, feare not.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Would I were at it once.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, because she desires to bee private, goe in with your wife Mr. Brittleware, take a roome, call for a feast, and satisfie your wife, and bid the Mrs: of the house to provide for us.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And how doe you feele your selfe Mr. Hoyden after your bleeding, purging, and bathing, the killing of your grosse humors by your spare dyet, and your new infusion of pure blood, by your queint feeding on delicate meates and drinks? how doe you feele your selfe?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Marry I feele that I am hungry, and that my shrimped yet and sippings have almost famished me, and my purse too; slid I dare be sworne, as I am almost a gentleman, that every bit and every spoonfull that I have swallowed these ten dayes, has cost me ten shillings at least.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Is it possible that you can consider this, and bee almost a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Small acquaintance I doe not lye to you: truth's truth, as well in a Gentleman as a begger, for I am both almost, and perhaps not the first that can write so.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Doe you note how his wit rises?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: There's one of my hundred pounds gone that way, all but these twelve pieces.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: You see now what a fine hand you have made of your money, since you got it out of my clutches.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Then there's my apparell, a hundred pound went all in three suits, of which this is the best.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But what doe you thinke of your wit hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Marry I thinke that was the best laid out: for by it I have got wit enough to know that I was as cleerely cosen'd of it as heart can wish: o' my soule and conscience, and as I am almost a gentleman, and a man had come to London for nothing else but to be Cheated, hee could not bee more roundlier rid of his money.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Well sir, if you repine at your expences now, that you want nothing but your Belly-full of Sparagus to finish my worke of a gentleman in you; I will, if you please, in lieu of that stuffe up your paunch with Bacon and Bagge-pudding and put you
backe againe as absolute a Clowne as ever you came from plough.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I would he're come to that once.

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Take heed how you crosse him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Nay pray sir bee not angry, (though to the shame of a Gentleman I say it) my teeth doe ee'ne water at the name of the sweet Country dish you spoke of (bacon and bag-pudding) yet I will forbeare it: but you say I shall fill my belly with this new Daintrill that you spake of; these Sparowbills, what doe you call'hem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall have your belly full.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Top full I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Coul
sp.p: Humh—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall: but I must tell you, I must ha you turn away this grumbling Clowne that followes you: he is as dangerous about you, as your fathers blood was within you, to crosse and hinder your gentility.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: True, you said you would help me to a boy no bigger than a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And you shall have him, a pretty little knave, you may put him in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Yes wusse, to pick's money out if he had it; shortly 'twill come to that bevore't be long.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Coulter you must to the plough again; you are too heavy a clog at the heeles of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I with all my heart, and I con you thanks too.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The Clowne, my fathers heire, will be glad of you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Have you an elder brother?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You doe not heare me say he is my brother; but the clown my father had a former son, by a former wife, that was no gentlewoman as my mother was, and he is a Clowne all over, and incurable, even get you to him, like to like will agree well: here's a Crowne for you, 'twill carry you a foote to Tanton; and so get you gone like a Clowne as you are.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: 'Tis well you allow me some mon ey yet: we shall have you begge all the way home shortly, when your Cheaters have done we 'yee.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How villaine!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why doe you not correct him sir?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Nay why do not you, he dares not? though he could spare his Clowne blood, he dares not venture his Gentleman blood so, nor you yours, tis all too fine I doubt; therefore keepe it, & make much on't: I would be loath a jaile should stay my journey, or by my Cursen soule I would see, what colour the best on't were before I goe. But if I don't your errand to your brother, and tell'n how you doe vlout'em behinde's back, then say Cut's a Curre: And so a vart vor a varewell to the proudest o'yee; and if you be an anger'd, tak't in your angry teeth.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Mon. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What a rude Rascall 'tis? you are happy that he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And so am I, he hindred halfe my worke; seven yeares time is too little to make a gentleman of one that can suffer such a Clowne within seven mile of him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Would hee were beyond Brainford on his way then by this time for me. But you forget the way you were in; you said you would fill my belly; and then fall to practice fine complements and congies to make me a perfect gentleman, and fit to see mine unknowne uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: All shall be done.

div.head: Act 3. Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter Brittleware and Rebecca to them.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: See if my Surgeon and his wife have not fil'd themselves, and come wiping their lips already.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So shall you presently: now Landlady are you pleasd with your Asparagus?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: With the Asparagus I am; and yet but halfe pleas'd neither, as my husband shall very well know.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, wee will leave you to talke with him about it: come sir let us into the house.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: But halfe pleas'd sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p:
No indeed Iohn Brittleware; the Asparagus has done its part; but you have not done your part Iohn; and if you were an honest man Iohn, you would make sir Hughes words good of the Asparagus, and be kinder to me: you are not kinde to your owne wife Iohn in the Asparagus way; you understand me: for ought
I see Pompeons are as good meat for such a hoggish thing as thou art.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Well, when we come at home Beck, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: At home, is't come to that? and I know what I know: I know he cannot love his wife enough at home, that won't bee kinde to her abroad: but the best is I know what my next longing shall be.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: More longings yet! now out of the unsearchable depth of womans imagination, what may it be?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It beginnes to possesse me already, still more and more: now tis an absolute longing, and I shall be sick till I have it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: May I know it forsooth, tell it that you may have it.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I dare tell it you, but you must never know that I have it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: If you dare tell it.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Dare; nay be as jealous as you will: thus it is, I do long to steale out of mine owne house, unknowne to you as other women doe, and their husbands nere the wiser, hither to this same Sparagus Garden, and meet some friend that will be kind to me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: How, how!

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: In private; unknowne to you, as I told you; 'tis unpossible I shall ever have a child else, and you so jealous over me as you are?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Art thou a woman and speak this?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Art thou a man, five yeares married to me; and aske mee now if I be a woman?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Art thou so full of the Devill to flye out in this manner?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why his hornes flye not out of me to fright thee, do they?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Oh for a hell that has not a woman in't?

div.head: Act 3. Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter a Gentleman and a City Wife.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Look you there Iohn jealousie, there's an example before your eyes, if nothing hang i'your sight; there you may see the difference between a sower husband and a sweet natur'd gentleman! good heart! how kindly he kisses her! and how feately she holds up the neb to him! little heart! when will you be so kind to your owne wife Iohn.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Is that his wife thinke you?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: No, no, I know her, tis Mris. Holy-hocke the precise Drapers wife; oh, how my longing growes stronger in mee: J see what shift soever a woman makes with her husband at home, a friend does best abroad.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Jndeed my Mris. will not take this money, there wants two shillings.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why is my peece too light?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Two light for the reckoning Mrs. it comes to two & twenty shillings, and this is but twenty.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Vnreasonable; how can she reckon it,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: J know what you had sir, and we make no bills:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Well fare the Taverns yet, that though they cosen'd never so much, would downe with it one way or other: and their Iacks, go agen; now tell your Mris. & that wil hinder her somwhat.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Not a jot sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Then tell her the Countesse of Copt Hall is comming to be her neighbour againe, and she may decline her trade very dangerously.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Mris. scorns your words sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You Rogue

sp.speaker: Wom..
sp.p: Nay sweet Cosen, make no uprore for my reputations sake; here youth there's two shillings more, commend me to your Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: She payes the reckoning it seems.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It seems then he has beene as kind to her another way.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How is't? J hope you are not wrangling now, but better pleas'd than so.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: No, no, sir Hugh, 'tis not the Sparagus can do't, unlesse the man were better:

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But may J now be confident that J am almost a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Without that confidence you are nothing.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There wants nothing now, but that you learn the rules & rudiments, the principles and instructions for the carriages, congies, & complements, which we'll quicly put into you by practice.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And then the spending the little rest of my mony, & J am a cleare gentleman, & may see my uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Right, right.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And I will write it, and crowd it into as many Bonds as I can a purpose to write gentleman; Timothy Hoyden of Tanton— no, of London, Gentleman: London is a common place for all gentlemen of my ranke, is it not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Excellent, doe you not marke how finely he comes on?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But as I hope to live and dye a gentleman Mrs. what shi' call', your reckoning was devillish deare: s'daggers three pound for a few Cuckoe pintles, they were no better I thinke.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Now you fall backe againe, and derogate from the condition of a gentleman most grosly, to think any thing too deare you eate or drinke.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Poxe on't, I had forgot.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: When he has his rules and principles, which must be his next study, he will remember.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Pray let's about it quickly.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now we'll goe; but you forget me Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No indeed sir Hugh, here's two Peece for last week and this.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Tis well: Landlord and Landlady will you goe?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Would you wou'd long to be at home once.

sp.speaker: Wif..
sp.p: Wif I doe perhaps and to be here againe, and there again; and here, and there, and here againe; and all at once.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Hey kicksie winsie.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And I doe long to goe to Windsor too, to know if the prophesie is as true there, as he reported here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How did you heare it goes forsooth?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: That all old women shall die, and many young wives shal have Cuckolds to their husbands.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I heard forsooth that all young wives should dye that were pure maids when they were marryed.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And none other?

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: So report goes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: You speake very comfortably: It may be a long journey to the worlds end yet.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: It seems you are not proscribed by the prophesie then?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thank my destiny.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
My first worke when I am compleat gentleman shall bee
to get them a Child, and make 'hem friends.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A most gentlemanly resolution.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And truely the City is much bound to such well affected gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: IS it possible that halfe this can be true, that a halfe brother of mine can be made such an asse all over?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Tis all true, as I am a Cursen fellow Mr. Thomas, every word on't: ● scorne to lye in a sillibub I; what lucke had I to meete you? I never thought to zee you at London.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: S'daggers death, it has as good as veez'd me out o'my wits to think on't: was my vathers blood zo quaisome to him, (with a mischiefe to't) that he must let it out to be a gentleman, because his mother was one (by her owne report:) for our own parts we nother know nor care where hence she coame, nor whither she's gone, but dead she is) she brought my vather a good purse o' mony, and kept another in store it seems, till she could keep't no longer, and then bestow'd it well and wisely upon Chitty vace her zonne, to make him a geantleman, and told him what great house he coame on by her side; for shee was a Striker forzooth, and ga'n directions to vinde an old Uncle of his here in Cuckold-shire, one Mr. Striker: but virst shee bade him put his zelfe into vashion, and bee sure to beare's zelfe like a Gentleman; and he has ta'ne a wise course to compasse it, it zeems: I warrant he ha made a voole o' his voure hundred pound by this time.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Ay, and o'his zelfe too, as his Cony catchers ha handled him: And you had zeen't, you would ha' bepist your zelfe vor woe, how they blooded him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then how they spurg'd his guts out.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Colt.
sp.p: A Bots light on 'hem, 'twould ha made a dog zick to zeet how like a scalded pig he look'd.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then how they did veed'ne with a zort of zlip zlaps not all worth a' messe o' milke porredge to make him vine vorsooth.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Youle zee zuch an altrication in him as never was zeen in a brother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But I wo'not zee'n yet as voule a Clowne, as I am, and as vine a gentleman, as he is, I have a tricke i'my skonce to make a yonger brother o'me.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I that would be zeene now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I ha't, and 'tis a vine one, I came to London to zeeke the voole my brother, and ha the same directions from our Curate, (to whom my mother told all) that Tim had to vinde his uncle Strikers house, and I ha quir'd it out; and this is it, and thou zhalt zee what I chill doe now: wh'are within.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Who would you speak with.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: By your leave vorsooth, I would speake with the Mr. o' the house: I understand his worships name is Mr. Striker.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He is so sir, but he is not in case to buy any cattell at this time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nor doe I come to zell'n any; my comming is of a dead bodyes errand vorsooth.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What strange fellow is this troe?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I pray vorsooth, and you bee old enough (as it zeems you be) to remember when my mother was a maid, did you know a zuster of Mr. Strikers that was married into Zummerzet shire?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What was her name I pray?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Her Cursen name was Audry, she zed, and a Striker she as bevore she was married; but my vather made a Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes Hoyden, zo I zay; there be very good vokes o' th name, as you shall well know; I cham one my zelfe, and she neede not be asham'd I wusse o' the kin she coame on, to hugger mugger it as she did to her dying day.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Most wonderfull, but is she dead?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes vaith she's dead, and as sumptiously buried, though I zay't, as any yeomans wife within ten mile of Tanton, any time these ten and twenty yeare.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Pray what were you to her?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I tell you, my vather married her; and I should bee her zonne I thinke.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Good heaven, how things will come about!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Coulter keep thy countenance Coulter, Ile make 'hem believe I am her very naturall zonne, & zee what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Ile keepe my countenance, and zet a vace on't too and need be.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Your Vncle Striker at this time is very sicke sir, but I will acquaint him with your desire: pray walke into the next roome the while sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: If he should dye now Coulter, and make me his heire?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I marry Mr. so you might make a better journey on't then the gentleman your brother.

sp.speaker: Fris..
sp.p: This to me is the greatest wonder of all, that I am presently possess'd of my Mrs. sullen sicknes, which has ee'n drawn him to deaths doore, and my Mistresses unfortunable condition are nothing to this Country Hoydens relation:

div.head: Act 4. Scene 3.
div.p: O Mr. Touchwood, you are the welcom'st Gentleman that ever could come into so heavy a house.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A stinking one it is I am sure: that nasty carrion thy Mr. is i'my nose already, I think I were best goe no further.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Let not the sadnesse of this place dismay you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But is he dead already, ha?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Not altogether dead sir

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The worse luck; and how does your Mistris? ha, ha, ha, well well I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She is in bodily health sir, but very sad and much disconsolate, poore Damsell.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not for her Grandsire, is she: if the worst dogge hee keeps howle for him, Ile worry sheepe with mine owne teeth, and trusse for him; but why is she sad, prethee tel me? ha ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I marvaile at your mirth sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I would now give her a new Gowne, to tell me the true cause that I might save mine oath, and rore out my rejoycings: twas a devillish tricke of the Rascalls to bind me by oath never to speake of it, but to those that should tell me of it first. I have such a coyle to keep it in now: Prethee tell me, what has the old Traveller, that is now bound for the Low Countries, gi'n thy Mrs. in his will, canst tell?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Alas he is offended with her, she has displeased him in somewhat, that is the maine cause of his mortall sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: That's my boy, there boy, there, that was a home blow.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She comes not at him sir, nor dares not see him: do you know any thing by her sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: No, no, no, not I, not I; s'bones I bit my tongue too hard.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: If you doe sir, would you would speake a good word for her, that he may dye in charity with her.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The jade jeeres me, Ile stay no longer i'the house.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay good sir say not so, after so many messages and entreaties, by all the best o'the parish, and an exhortation made to you by the Minister himselfe: did you vouchsafe to come, and wil you now come short to see my Master, now the Doctors have given him over, and he is dying?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I confesse 'twas my desire to see that dying that brought me hither: where is he? Ile hold my nose, and have at him.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I hope you wil be friends with him now sir; for he's ee'n a going.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Friends? Ile rather goe with him, and fight it out by the way.

div.head: Act 4. Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Striker brought in a Chaire, Curate.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Looke you sir here he is.

sp.speaker: Touch,
sp.p: What up and in a Chaire?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes sir; he will not yield by any perswasion to dye in his bed.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then he may live to be hanged yet, for ought I see.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: See sir, your neighbour Touchwood comes to be reconciled to you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are quite besides the book sir Domine, I have no friends in hell to send to by him: no sir, I come to see him dye, as he liv'd a hatefull miscreant.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Let me pray and beseech you to speake more charitably, or else not to offend the dying man with your presence.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Doe I come to humour him, or you, or my selfe, thinke you: you that take upon you, and doe rather goe about to sooth him up in his sicknesse, then to fright him out of his paine, rather encourage him to live then rid the world of him, and his abhominations.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Best looke into your selfe Sir: The worlds a stage, on which you both are Actors, and neither to be his owne Judge.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But he has playd many vilde and beastly parts in it, let him goe, I would see his last Exit, and hisse him out of it; harke, the Ravens cry porke for him, and yet he dyes not.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O you are a hard-hearted man.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My heart's not hard enough to breake his, I would it were: where's your kinde hearted Mistris, fetch her, and trye what she can doe.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What have you done sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, so, so, so it workes, it workes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Out snarling Hell-hound my curse upon thee, and thy cursed sonne that has undone my Neece and mee: curse upon curse light on yee.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.p: Oh fearefull.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How heartily he prayes; sure he is neare his end.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pray sir depart, you are too uncharitable.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My sonne undone thy Neece: has he not done her think'st thou? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh: Villaine thou knowst what he has done; huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know not whether I know or no; tell me, and Ile tell thee.

lg.l: Ile tell you then that which you know already,
Although you keepe it for a joy within you:
Your wicked sonne has by her owne confession
Done that unto her, that unlesse he play
The honest mans part and marry her, he will
Full dearely answer it in Hell.

sp.speaker: Stri:
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Speake English, has he laine with her?

lg.l: Tis so:
She has confest it to her grandfather,
To me, and Mr. Pancridge here is made
Acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: The Virgin sayes
She is depusilated by your sonne.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Depusilated, ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: It is no laughing matter: therefore send
Speedily for your sonne, before the rumour
Make it ridiculous; as yet none knowes it,
But we a slender few.
Will you direct
Your Divine Rhetoricke there to him; and winne him
But to entreat me in this case, and try
What I will say to't.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Be perswaded sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: In this extremity I doe entreat you that they may marry.

lg.l: I have my ends upon thee; quickly dye,
And take thine owne, thy base submission
Has rendred thee more odious, more loathsome
To me than all thy former villanies.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh huh.

lg.l: And harke thee ere thou dyest, for now th'art going:
Before my sonne shall wed that whore thy Neece,
She shall bring all the hands of all the whore-masters
In City, Court, and Kingdome, (black Coats, and all)
I will spare none) unto a faire Certificate
That she is cleare of all men but my sonne,

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh.

lg.l: Nay more:
That she is cleare of him too; and that hee
Has never top'd her in the way we treat of,
Before he wed her: for my sonne shall not ride
In his old boots upon his wedding night:
So, now dye and sinke
Into thy grave, to rid us of thy stinke.

sp.speaker: Cure.
sp.p: I have not knowne such want of charity.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Vnconscionable wretch, thou hast kild my Mr.

lg.l: Vgh, ugh, no Fid ugh hem! he has cur'd me:
I am light at heart agen: he has cur'd me;
He has play'd the good Physitian 'gainst his will;
And a halter be his fee for't.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The Devill I have, and his Dam it shall.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ah hem! I am light at heart agen.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O damn'd old counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Well fare your heart old Master.

lg.l: Though she prove bastard-bellyed, I will owne her,
Cherish, maintaine, and keepe her from thy sonne.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Oh I could teare that tongue out.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Keep her child too.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Doe, and her next, and fill thy house with bastards.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ile hold 'hem more legitimate than thy brood.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What meane you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: For thou, thy sonne, thy house is all a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Beare witnesse, he calls my house a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Touch
sp.p: Ile make thy house to smoak for't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Beare witnesse there, he saies he will fire my house.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: For neighbour-hood and Charity speak lower.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Tis' petty treason; ile be wi'yee there sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And hang thy selfe old scare Crow.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Will you eate a peece of Ginger-bread for your Winde Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Out Witch.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ile lay as many actions on thee as thou hast bones in that Swines foote of thine.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: My Nailes shall right me: Ile teach him to kick a woman.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hold mistris Friswood.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O Villaine kicke a woman!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou laidst this plot to murther me, thou man-killer.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Blood-sucker thou ly'st.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Helpe from above, within, or any whence, in the name of sanctity I conjure you. Flectere si nequeo superos, Acheronta movebo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What's the matter? by your leave which is my zick Uncle? are you scuffling for's money before he be dead.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Wee'l part you with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha you your Tennants, your Clownes here brought in to butcher me?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Slave they are thine, brought in to spoyle and rob mee; I know 'hem not.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I feare I have conjur'd up fiends indeed, how infernally they looke?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No sir, we come with no zick intendment on neither nother zide; but an you be Mr. Striker, we are o'your zide, an't bee to cut all the rest into Pot-hearbs.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: No, this is my Mr.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Zay but the word then, and have at 'hem.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Had you your ambuscado for me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: They are a paire of the Sedan Mules I take it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Moyles sir, wee be no Moyles would you should well know.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We be Cursen folke as good as your zelfe, and get you out o'the house by mine Vncles leave here.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your Vncle, oh brave.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Or if I baste you not well a fine, and Lamb-skinne your jackets till your bones rattle i'your hides, then zay cha bewrai'd the house I coame on.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Well sir, Ile goe and leave you to your Vncle: rejoyce
sir with your kind red: I hope you wil have more shortly, if your Neece prove fruitful: Come Master Paneridge, will you goe?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: With joy for your recovery, and manners to your privacy, Right Worshipfull I leave you to talke with 'Clowne your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Tarry, tarry; as sure as a Club, this Clowne is sent for out of the Country, to soder up his crack'd Neece in Matrimony, and therefore calls him Vncle; I could spoyle the Match, but by my oath I dare not; and therefore Clowne take thy course: come let us goe Mr. Pancridge

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And why you my Nephew sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And why not I your Nephew; han't she told you, and ha'not I told you as much as the matter's worth, and doe yee meane to vlee from the bargaine?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What new afflictions hourely find me out?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And for your health, I hope sir.

lg.l: Sir, Ile have better testimony then your owne;
Tis true I lost a sister; but till you
Bring stronger proofe she was your mother sir,
Your Clowneship must not Vncle me; am I we'you sir?
Kings Crownes have beene pretended to by' impostures;
And knavery is as rife in Russet Wooll,
As in the prowdest purple; get you gone,
There I am we'you directly.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is't come to this now?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Your project will not hold Mr. Thomas, best zeek your brother Tim, hee has a zertification from the parish, and the Priest too, of all your mothers mind, and you could cosen him on't, and come agen, and uncle this weese gentleman, whether he wooll or no; 'twould be vine i'vaith

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Agreed: well sir, vor this time I ha no more to zay t'yee, since you be so budge: but he that made you zave you

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Farewell sir, I doe beginne to think there's something in't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He made me thinke he was your sisters sonne I am sure.

lg.l: I will not think so, no he was set on
By some of my maligners to abuse me;
It had beene good to ha laid him by the heeles:
But let him goe; call downe my Neece out of
The melancholy mist she's chambred in, Ex. Fris.
All makes for her; their vexing me, restores
Her to my love againe; and reason good;
She's mine owne naturall Neece: and though
She has lost the husband, and the name she sought,
Yet she appeares a Striker; and I will cherish her.
Come you shal grieve no longer, I am friends wi'yee:
Stand up, stand up I say, and look up too,
Off with this mourning veile, and dry those teares:
I have consider'd that right Noble Parents
Have pardon'd in their Children as great faults;
But let it bee your warning, not your licence.
For your security I am content,
And would entreat to live in that retirement,
Which your faire Justice, and my foule offence
Of late confin'd mee to, to weepe and sigh
My loathed life away.
No more: you shall
No longer live reclus'd in wilfull darknesse;
Enjoy your former liberty; see, and be seene:
And (as you weigh my pardon and my love)
Let not your blemish dwell upon your face;
Nor any argument of griefe, or shame
Be legible there, to the most curious eye:
But let your cheek be chearefull, and your brow
Crown'd with as great a confidence, as may
Comply with Virgin Modesty: and that
Adde to your beauty with full strength of Art,
Beyond the eye to take a lovers heart.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: In all I will obey you,

lg.l: If I make
Choise of a husband for you then, you'le take him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Twill but become my duty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: A good girle.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Sir here's the Knight come againe, that has been here in the time of your sicknesse to have seene you, and my Mistris, but
could not: and left a letter for you once: hee that looks women through so.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Oh Sir Arnold Cautious: did you tell him I was o' the mending hand.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes I told him you were so, so.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Give me my Gowne and Cap though, and set mee charily in my sickly chaire; his letter is a treaty of a match betwixt his Nephew and my Neece: goe fetch him up.
In Neece, and be not seene untill I call you: untill you heare me call you, doe you heare?
Could I but catch this Cautious coxecombe Knight now— Ile put faire for't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Here is the Knight sir.

lg.l: Why reach you not a Chaire? I hope sir Arnold
You'll pardon the necessity of my rudenesse:
I cannot rise, nor stoope, to you, uh, uh, uh.
Rather excuse me sir, that presse upon you
Thus in your weaknesse: but you understand
My businesse by my letter if you have read it.
Yes sir, goe forth; but be not farre I pray you. Ex. Fris.
I have heard your Nephew is a wilde yong man.
A very bashfull boy I assure you; that's the reason
That I am wonne to be a spokes-man for him.
Oh no dissembling sir; you know he is wilde,
And suffers under your displeasure for't: uh, uh, uh.
A witch could not gesse righter: but they say
That dying men are Prophets oftentimes.
Suppose he has beene wild, let me assure you
He's now reclaim'd, and has my good opinion:
And is as like in person and behaviour
To gaine the maids affection.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Speake to the purpose; pray what's his estate?

lg.l: I there's the poynt indeed: why sir, he has
A hundred pound a yeare; and is withall
A hopefull, and a handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hopefull, and handsome! uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You sir have wealth enough.

lg.l: And she has choise enough
Of greater matches: could I get her
Into a marriage vaine, but she'll not look
Upon a man not she; but lives retir'd
Here in my house, and is a carefull Nurse:
She's fitter sir to be an old mans Nurse,
Then any young mans bride: uh, uh, uh, uh.
Is she so grave in youth? I have often sought
A sight of her, but never could obtaine it.
Not without my consent I warrant you;
Shee's nearer to a mother than a maid.
I tell you truth sir, and you know deceipt
Becomes not dying men: uh, uh, uh. For vertue and obedience
She's fitter for your selfe then for your Nephew:
But to the poynt, a hundred pound a yeare
You say he has, and hopes and handsomnesse,
Which may acquire, with your assurance of
So much for joynture— Yes, a thousand pound
In portion with her: but sir let me tell you,
I'de rather give sixe thousand unto one
Of mine owne choise; which she will not refuse,
If I but say this is the man, and take him.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Will not your Neece be seene: I faine would see her.

lg.l: At hand: she will not out of my presence sir,
Nor ever was by man, not since the clocke
Of her Virginity struck eleven, not she,
Except at doore or window, as men passe:
And so perhaps your Nephew may have seene her.
Introth no otherwise; and so he told me.
May not I see her sir?
I tell you true;
Deceit you know becomes not dying men: uh, uh, uh.
And therefore harke you sir, I have a purpose,
(That if she take the man whom I will chuse)
To make her my sole heire; provided that
She match before I dye: uh, uh, I cannot last.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray let me see your Neece.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Friswood— why Friswood.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is that her name?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: No sir, I call my maid.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A maid; I took her for an old woman.

lg.l: A maid upon my vertue: and I feare
That her frigidity has mortifi'd my Neece:
Deceipt becomes not dying men you know
Friswood I say, I bad her not be farre:
I dare not straine my selfe to call her lowder.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Ile call her for you sir: Fris—

lg.l: Hold sir, hold, pray use this whistle for me,
I dare not straine my selfe to winde it I,
The Doctors tell me it will spend my spirits, Caut. whistles.
So, so, enough sir— Fie, fie upon you:
Goe call my Neece, uh, uh.
Be of good cheare sir, and take courage man:
What you have beene a Striker in your dayes:
And may be agen, I would not have him dye.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh— alas I cannot last— why comes she not?

lg.l: I cannot get her from her work; nor to
Beleeve me that you sent for her, because
I told her that a gentleman was with you
There was your fault, then I must call my selfe.
Why Anna-bell, ah, ah, ah, An-na-bell.
Take heede, straine not your selfe too hard, but send agen:
The rarest beauty that I e're beheld, Act 4. Scene 2.
Which with a maiden-head of that growth, Enter Annabell.
Would be an absolute wonder, her sweet modesty,
And meeke obedience, justifies that too, She kneeles at Strikers feet.
And makes her up a miracle of nature;
My former misbeliefe I doe renounce,
And at first sight, (which is the birth of love)
A faith growes in me, strengthened by the word
Of this expiring man, that chastity
Has not forsaken beauty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You shall heare him.

lg.l: What to propound a husband? honour'd sir,
Although I rather wish to dye a Virgin;
Yet my obedience to your grave behests
Shall sway my will: your choise shall be my liking:
But let me thus much favour begge, before
You make that choyse, that you will not destroy
The building you have rear'd; your care and cost
Hath built me up by vertuous education,
Vnto that heighth that I consider heaven;
And waxe so old in that high contemplation,
That to look downe on youthfull vanities,
Were to be at a stand; and to delight in 'hem,
Were to fall backe againe; and to be link'd
In marriage, to a man whose wilde affections
Are bent to worldly pleasures a maine perdition.
I dare not speak to her for my Nephew now:
Nor (though I love her strangely) for my selfe.
Doe you tell me of his Nephew sir? even hee
The Knight himselfe, I hold to be too young
For a well govern'd man as the world goes.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I ha' not the heart to wrong her; she's too good.

lg.l: Sir, here's a gentleman presses at my heeles
To speak with you.

div.head: Act. 4. Scene 8
div.stage: Enter Gilbert with his arme in a Scarffe.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Mr. Goldwire, what's your haste?

lg.l: I come to crye you mercy, and this good gentleman;
And this sweet Gentlewoman, who I take it
Is his faire Neece, of whom you are in treaty;
If it be not already gone too farre;
Let me entreate you not to put your finger
Further i'the businesse in behalfe of your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You first mov'd me to't.

lg.l: Tis that repents me:
Your base unworthy Nephew has abus'd me;
I doe not speake it for a slight hurt he has gi'n me,
But for his breach of Faith to another Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh me; and would you speak for such a man?

lg.l: And the false way, the plot he had upon you,
To put you on this enterprize, the Quarrell
In which he rescu'd you, to indeere himselfe to you,
Was a meere counterfeit squable, a very tricke
Contriv'd betwixt him and his brother Poet
T'abuse your goodnesse:
J leave it to your consideration sir:
I am in haste; and so I wish you health sir;
And you much happinesse in a husband Lady.
Has given me here a letter; I want but
Place fit to peruse it.
Had he a plot upon me, Ile have my plot too;
And now woe for my selfe sir if you please.
Sir, let me tell you, I thinke well of you, uh, uh,
Deceipt becomes not dying men you know,
Shee would make ee'ne too good a wife for you:
For I have heard sir of your disposition,
Never to marry without best assurance,
First, of Virginity, and then of Chastity,
In her that you would chuse; and let me tell you, uh, uh,
I know not where you can so well be fitted:
She's right, uh, uh, if you dare take a weak mans word,
Deceipt would ill become me, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I take you at your word, and thanke you sir.

lg.l: Vh, uh, uh, uh— O lay me in my bed:
You need not leave me yet sir.
No sir, no,
It shall be a match, or no match ere I goe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: NOw sir have you your rules by heart?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Both Rules and Rudiments I have al ad unguem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Repeate your Principles.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
Principles to be imprinted in the heart of every new made gentleman: To commend none but himselfe: to like no mans wit but his owne: to slight that which he understands not: to send mony, & never look for't agen: to take up upon obligation, & lend out upon affection: to owe much, but pay little: to sell land, but buy none: to pawn, but never to redeem agen: to fight for a whore:
to cherish a Bawd, and defie a trades-man.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And can you observe and keepe these rules thinke you?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I hope I can sir, and have begunne pretty well already: you see I have spent and lent all my money; and pawn'd all my Cloaths but these a' my backe, as I am a cleare gentleman; and for the rest of the rudiments, and the severall carriages and deportments by garbe, by congy, complement, &c. which are to be attain'd by practice when I come abroad and amongst 'hem, you shall gaine credit by me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I commend your confidence: now Mr. Springe, and Mr. Brittleware, play you the Complementasters before him a little, for his further instruction: Imagine them a couple of Courtiers scarcely acquainted fall to; and looke that you congy in the new French Bum-trick; here Landlord, take his Cloak and hat to appeare more generous.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Bum tricke!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come meet and begin; play but two or three bouts at most at single Rapier complement, and one or two at Back-sword and you ha done: now observe sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Single Rapier, and Back-sword Complement foyle.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Noble Master Fine-wit, the single example of Court-Ceremony, if my apprehension deale fairely with me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Sir, how auspiciously have I falne upon the knowledge of you by vertue of the same apprehension.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So, there's one.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What's here?

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Peace, let's see a little more.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman, a neate bout and fairely come off o' both sides.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, I shall ever blesse the promptnesse of my memory, in being so fortunate to collect the fallacious acquaintance of so compleat a goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir I shall ever blesse, &c.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p:
Oh you are pleas'd out of that noble worth which can convert all things to the forme and image of its owne perfection
to make your selfe glorious, with that which is miserably impoverish'd in it selfe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good, there's two.

sp.speaker: Hoy,
sp.p: Miserably impoverisht in it selfe— oh sweet.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, you have such a conquering way in humility, that hee shall be sure to come off vanquish'd that offers to contend with you.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: This is the noblest of all humanity to peece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your owne.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A plaine hit that: here were three bouts well plaid.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Peece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your owne: most stately fine, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So much for single Rapier: now for your secret wipe at Back-sword.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I that I would see, like the hackling of the Millers leggs: now for a delicate back-blow.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: See you yon fellow I held complement with?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Yes sir, a well-spoken gentleman and a lovely.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The arrantst trifle in a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: What he is not, is he?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Made onely to make physicke worke: a very lumpe of laughter.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You have done well: now you sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Doe you note him yonder that past from you?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: That gallant sir?

lg.l: The very scorne at Court;
So empty, not one passable part about him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: A very tilting stocke for yong practisers to break their jests on.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Good and enough; doe you call this good enough, to abuse one another thus?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, this is qacksword Complement: this wipes off the false praise which the first thrust on: you must bee seene in both, or you are no true garbist else.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: J shall soonest hit o'this; for from a whelpe I could give scurvey language.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now break in upon 'hem; save you sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O course salutation: save you sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How got you hither gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Here we are sir, and have seene part of your practice, your Courtly exercise.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Peace: but how got you in, and a stranger with yee?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He shall betray nothing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: We found faire entrance into the house.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: 'Sfoot where's my wife then?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: If your wife be the gentlewoman o' the house sir, shee's now gone forth in one o' the new Hand-litters: what call yee it, a Sedan.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: O Sedana.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He's runne mad with his hornes.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: He's runne with my Hat and Cloak by your leave.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He'll come agen, neare doubt him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You say so small acquaintance; but I could ne're see any thing of mine againe, since I came amongst you, if it once got out of my sight: what money have I left troe?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I pray gentlemen which way took she:

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Downe towards the Strand I tell you, in a new Litter, with the number one and twenty in the breech on't.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: A Litter of one and twenty in her breech: High time to runne.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You see we have our plot in action too, sir Hugh, and it runnes fairely on.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But what a rogue art thou to put such a slur upon thine owne Vncle; first to put him on for thy selfe, then you with a Counterfeit tricke to put him off o' that course, to runne desperately headlong to breake his owne necke in a match: what a Rogue art thou to use thine uncle thus?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay what a wretch were you, if you should crosse your daughter in such a fortune?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Which if I doe, cut my wind-pipe: what the yong rascall Touchwood is gone into France they say?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I he's safe enough.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sir Cautious to be catch'd! if I doe not love my daughter the better for her lucky leg stretching, I am a villaine, I am taken with such kind of roguery.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Take heed you have not a crosse plot in that itching pate of yours to spoyle all now.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Then cut my weasond I say.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And I sweare I will, or cut these hands off; I thought good to tell you so, because I know what tricks you have done, & what discoveries you have made for small parcells of ready money.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Hoo poxe, I want no money; now look there comes Mr. Hoyden, salute these gallants.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: What without a hat or cloak?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The better for a young beginner.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir, I shall ever blesse my auspicious starres, that shin'd me into the falicious acquaintance of so singular goodnes.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir you forget your selfe.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Most singular sweet sir, most miserably impoverish't in it selfe.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Good sir forbeare, make not an Idoll of me.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You peece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your owne.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Can you say this gentleman was a Clowne within this fortnight?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Within this fortnight I assure you sir, as rank a Clown o' one side, as ever held Cow to Bull.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Had it beene o' both sides, it had beene miraculous.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Now note me sir: doe you see that fellow I left?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, tis my friend.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The arrantest coxcomb in a Country

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Made onely to make Physick worke.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You doe not know him sure.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: A tilting stocke for young practisers to break jests on: there's a wipe for you at backe sword Complement.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: There's another for you sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You knock at the wrong doore sir, and I pitty your ignorance: goe to schoole as I have done, and learn more wit: kick a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Here he is and here be all the crue on 'hem, and more.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Here? thou mockst he is not here: sure these be all Lords I thinke.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How now; what's he?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Slid 'tis his Clowne brother he spake of?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is't possible? icha made a sweet jaunt after you & have I vound a vine voole o'thee: where's thy voure hundred pound? is that made a voole on too troe: where's the zartificate my mother ga' thee to vinde thine uncle? gi' me that, Ihill see what I can doe wi'it.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Away Clowne I know thee not canst thou complement?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Complement lyes, I can complement dagger out o'sheath, an I zet on't.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I hope he'll veeze you, and make your zilken jacket hum: well zed Mr. Thomas to 'hem, and to 'hem all Ile zide yee.

sp.speaker: Gil. Wat. Sam.
sp.p: Mr. Thomas does he call him?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Thomas, and what zay you to that; and as good a Mr. as the best o'yee, and you goe to that; for by uds shall judge me, I think you are all but a company of Cheaterlings; and if you doe not give the voole my brother sartifaction for the wrongs you ha'd one him, and me in him, Ile canvas it out o' the carkasses o'zome o'yee, by uds daggers death will I. Draw Coulter, & amongst 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Hold sir, hold, you shall have satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O shall I zoe, put up againe Coulter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: This is a stout roring Clowne.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Where's the Mr. o' the house?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He's runne mad, after his wife, now he should look to his house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Cha mich a doe to vorbeare beating o'thee yet, my vingers doe zo itch at thee.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I understand thee not, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But now I thinke on't Coulter, we'll have all againe, & by a quieter way; and teach 'hem to licke hony, catch birds with Chaffe, or go to plow with dogs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; who understands the Barbarian tro?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Uds vish Master they do nothing but jeer to you all this while now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Doe they jeere, let 'hem jeer & gibe too; ile vetch ones Warrant shall out jeere 'hem all, and he be above ground.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall not need sir; go but in till the Mr. of the house comes home, you shall have your desire.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You zay very well sir; zay well is good, but doe well is better. Lets zee what you will doe now.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Remember we have warn'd you sir Hugh, we must leave you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay I'chill look to you: sirrah come in my hand.

lg.l: Now for a trick to rid us of this Clowne,
Or our trade sinks, and up our house is blowne.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Tis as I tell you Mr. Touchwood; your sonne has lost a faire fortune in the young gentlewoman, and as I conceive by your wilfulnes Sir Arnold Cautions licks his lips at her. I assure you; and a sweet lick it is, sixe thousand pound in present portion.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A sweet lick he has indeed if he knew all.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: He does know all sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: If he did, I know what I know; good oath let me not lose thy vertue.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: He knowes moreover, that Mr. Striker, her grandfather has covenanted to give her two thousand pound more at the birth of his first Child, lawfully begotten on her body.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; but what if her first child prove illegitimate?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: That is not to be thought sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, and spoken too, if I durst; but good oath let mee not lose thy vertue.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: And then he had entred into ten thousand pound bond, to leave her his heire if she survive him.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But he's well recover'd you say.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Very lusty, very lively sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then hang him, he'll never dye; I am a fear'd I must be faine to give him over, I shall never vexe him to death: no, no, I shall never do't.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: No sir, I heard himselfe say, that your vexing him has bin his physick, and the best meanes to keep him alive.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Did he say so? Ile teare this match in peeces presently: and see how that will worke on him; Ile do't, what's an oath to me, in respect of sending him to the Devill, Ile do't.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I would you could sir, and recover her for your son yet.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Vmh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Because I love the yong gentleman wel

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Vmh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Though I assure you the writings are all past, sign'd, seal'd, and delivered; but I have 'hem in my hands yet, and can doe you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Humh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: And came purposely to advise you, because I loue your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Vmh— what a world of villany lies in the jobber noule of a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Thinke of it sir, and be speedy.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Right learned in the Law, and my sons friend Mr. Trampler, Mr. Ambodexter Trampler, you are a most notorious knave, & and you shall heare on't o'both sides, as you take fees.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Nay, and you be so hot Mr Touchwood I am gone.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know my course; either I will crack the heart-strings of Striker, in crossing this match, with the crack'd credit of his Neece, or else I will be friends with him, and that will kill him out right: But my oath still troubles me— Oh gentlemen you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Ha you heard sir of your sonne yet?

lg.l: Not I, he lacks no money yet it seems:
Young Travellers make no other use of their fathers.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But ha you heard the newes of his young Mistris?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What of sir Cautious being catcht, the wise and wary gentleman, your Vncle, that would not beleeve there could be a marriagable maid, thogh she were justified by a jury of Midwifes, and therefore purpos'd to have dy'd a Batchelour: that he should now bee catch'd with a pipt Nut-shell, and a Maggot in't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sure he was strangely wrought to't.

lg.l: I you must think
There have beene knavish heads us'd in the businesse.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But I wil crosse it and their knaveries, what ere they are.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I hope you will not crosse mine uncle in such a fortune tho.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What to marry a wench?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, so much wealth sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Pray let me use my Christian Liberty, my Conscience pricks me to't, it must be done.
Now what say you sir?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: We might ha spar'd this labour: he was resolv'd before we came it seemes to spoyle the marriage.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We could not bee too sure though: wee are now sure enough, that our disswasions will spur him on the faster.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And we are no lesse sure, that sir Hugh Mony-lacks will set his strength to life Sir Cautious off o'the hooks, in hope of a matter of 5. Pound, though he forfeit the obligation of his throat by't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: All the danger is, that Sir Hugh wil be with mine Uncle too soon, & prevent the match before he be too deep ingag'd in't.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: For that my letter of instructions, which I have given Annabell shall prevent him; and Striker keeps Sir Cautious in his house so warily, that untill the intended wedding houre, Sr. Hugh shall not obtaine admittance.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Goe fetch 'hem in, and make the warrant: ha, ha, ha: Gentlemen will you heare a complaint my man tells mee of certaine Clownes that desire my warrant to apprehend for notorious Cheaters, whom doe you thinke?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I cannot ghesse.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I know none I hope.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Even Sir Hugh Money-lacks, the mourning Knight, and some of his associats.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O'my life it is the roring Clowne, about the new made Gentleman his brother.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What is it you sir, Mr. Strikers Nephew, as I take it, you cald his great worships Vncle lately as I take it, and did your best to tore me out of his house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Zheart Coulter we be vallen into the Bakers ditch.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And doe you bring your complaints to me sir, ha?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Zet a good vace on't; and veare no colours though.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I am an honest man, and a true man for all that, and I thought you the vittest to make my complaint to because you were the next Justice, to as pestilence a peece of villany as ever you were Master of in all your life: I come but vor justice, and to pay vor what I take, and't be avore hand, here it is, whether it be vor your Clarke or your zelfe, who makes or meddles with it, your man has my complaint in writing, pray let me have your warrant.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: You shal, but first tell me, how came it that you cald that Striker uncle.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Vor cause that he is uncle to a voole that I ha' to my brother, and I thought I might be so bold wee'n, and he was not against it at virst, till you were gone, and then he bad me goe zeek better testimony, and so I went and vound my brother Tim, his owne zusters zonne I assure yee.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: His Sisters sonne?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Where he was made such a Tim, as ne're was heard on in Tonton, amongst a many Cheaters: by masse here are a couple o'm.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: These were o'the crew.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How now my Masters: sure fellow thou art mistaken.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No sir, I am not mistaken I but I take 'hem I, where I vinde 'hem I: And I charge your justiceship with 'hem I, til they bring out my brother I.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Bring out your brother: why what has your brother done?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Done: nay they have done and undone him amongst 'hem. And I think devour'd him quick too vor he is lost, & no where to be vound.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Doe you know the meaning of any of this gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: If he were your brother sir, that you found at Sir Hugh Money-lacks lodging, you know we left him in your hands.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We stept in but by chance, & such a youth we found there, & there we left him in your and their hands, that had the managing of him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Zo you did, but what then did me the rest, but pli'd me, and my man Coulter here with wine, and zack, and something in't, I dare be zwore that laid us a zleep, when we mistrusted nothing but vaire play: oh speak Coulter, oh.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: And then when were vast azleep, they all gave us the zlip, the Knight was gon, and the Squire was gon, & Mr. Tim was gon, but he was made away, without all peraventure; for all the parrell that he wore was left behind: and then— speak Master.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And then the Mr o'the house came home, & made a monstrous wonderment for the losse of his wife; he could not vinde her he zed. and zo he vaire and vlatly thrust us out o'doores, and is gone a hunting after his wife agen: speak Coulter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Alas poore Britleware.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then we came for your warrant, to vind all these men agen.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And to take 'hem where we vinde 'hem, & these were zome on 'hem, when time was, and pray look to 'hem.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know not what to make o'this but sure there's something in't: And for these gentlemen ile see them forth-comming.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And I will undertake Sir Hugh Mony-lacks will be at the Bride-house.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And thither will I instantly.

sp.speaker: Gil. Wat.
sp.p: We'll waite upon you sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And I chill make bold to wait upon you till I be better zartified.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You shall, come on your way, come gentlemen.

lg.l: Well, here is such a knot now to untie,
As would turne Oedipus his braine awry.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Be appeas'd and comforted, good Mr. Britleware, trouble not your head in running after your fate, nor break your weighty braines in seeking wayes after your wives heeles, which are so light by your owne report, they cannot crack an egge.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Her credit yet they may and mine.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Besides your wife is your wife where e're she is abroad as we as at home, yea, lost perhaps as well as found: I am now going to yoke a heifer to a husband, that perhaps wil say so shortly: whither away Mr. Trampler?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: To the wedding house: where I thinke I saw your wife last night Mr. Britleware.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Did you sir, did you?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I cannot say directly; but I think 'twas she: does she not call the gentlewoman Aunt that keeps Mr. Strikers house?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes Mistris Friswood, she is her Aunt sir.

div.head: Scene 6.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come goe with us and find her.

div.stage: Enter the Sedan, Hoy. in it, in womans cloaths.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Pray gentleman stay, for I suppose She's here here's number one and twenty; & this is sure the litter.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: What peep you for; you ought not to do so sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: By what Commission ought you to carry my wife in a Close stoole under my nose

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: Tis a close Chayre by your leave: And I pray forbeare, you know not who we carry.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I know the cloaths she weares, and I will see the party.

sp.speaker: Hoy
sp.p: I know that voyce, & let me see the man; it is my surgeon.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: A Surgeon! I took you for a China shop-keeper Master Britleware; these by trades are for some by purposes, and I smell knavery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And Lawyers commonly are the best upon that sent.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Gentlemen this is a man that lay in my house.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A gentleman you would say, or my cost was ill besto'd there.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: These are my goods he weares; that was my mothers Gowne, and felloniously he weares it.

sp.speaker: Hoy
sp.p: Tis all I have to shew for foure hundred pound I laid out in your house; and Sir Hugh put it upon me, and hir'd these men to carry me— Whither was it?

sp.speaker: Lite-man.
sp.p: Vp to a lodging in St. Gileses sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Where he promis'd to finish his worke of a gentleman in me, and send me to my Vncle.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O monstrum horendum; a man in womens cloathes.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Tis fellony by the Law.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Has sir Hugh gin me the slip to finish his work in private? it shall all out, I am resolv'd, though I bewray my selfe in't: pray gentlemen assist me with this party to Mr. Justice Strikers, you say my wife is there.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Yes you shall thither.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And there Ile take a course you shal smel knavery enough.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I finde J am abus'd enough o' conscience: and shall be carried to mine Vncle now before my time and not as a gentleman, but as a gentlewoman, which grieves me worst of all.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hinc illae lachrimae, the youth is sure abus'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Hoy
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Come leave your crying: And you beasts up with your luggage, and along with us; ile fetch such drivers as shall set you on else.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: Let us be paid for our labour, and we'll carry him to Bride-well, if you please.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Oh, oh, that ever I was born in this groaning chaire.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It was well I sent for thee Neece, to helpe me decke the Bride here; and that the jealous foole thy husband thinkes thou art gone astray the while; it will be a meanes for thee to take thy liberty another night, and pay him home indeed, when he shall not have the power to mistrust thee: it is the common condition of Cuckolds to mistrust so much afore hand, that when they are Dub'd indeed, they have not a glympse of suspition left.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Their hornes hang in their light then; but truely Aunt, for mine owne part, I had rather my husband should be jealous stil then be cur'd in that right kinde; though I confesse the ends of all my longings, and the vexations I have put him to

lg.l: Were but to run his jealousie out of breath,
And make him pant under the frivolous weight
He beares; that is, a Cuckold in conceit;
Which without doubt he labours with by this time:
And when he finds me cleare, twill be as well:
(I hope) and better then if it were done
By the broad way of foule pollution.
Nay I doe not perswade you, take the downe-right way,
Nothing against your Conscience Neece; I sent
For him to ha come and found you here by chance;
But he has shut up house, and is runne mad
About the Towne I heare to all your haunts.
He shall come hither and renounce his jealousie,
And then entreat me too before I goe.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes, that's a wise wives part.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What's the Bride ready?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes sir, she's drest.

lg.l: And drest, and drest indeed;
Never was maid so drest: oh sir you are happy;
The happiest Knight, and are now in election
Of the most sweet encounter in a bride,
That e're your chivalry could couch a Lance at.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I thanke you Mrs. and Ile bring her shortly to bestow mony w'yee in China wares.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: She is her self the purest piece of Purslane— that e're had liquid sweet meats lick'd out of it.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And purer too I hope.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Go call her down.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She's at her private prayers yet sir, she.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: When she has done, then hasten her away.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Such Brides doe seldome make their grooms their prey.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Doe you now conclude Sir Arnold you are happy?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: As man can be being so neare a wife.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: He come? I fear a mischief.

lg.l: How comes it Father Striker, and sonne Cautious in election
That you huddle up a match here for my child,
And I not made acquainted, as unworthy,
Vntill the very intended marriage houre?
Who sent you hither, I sent not for you now sir:
And there I am wi' yee sir.
Tis true, I covenanted not to come at you,
Vntill you sent for me, unlesse you found
Young Touchwood had the love of Annabell,
You have heard he has touch'd her has he not?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Has he not made her Touchwood too?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Can you say so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, & struck fire too in her tinderbox.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not speak thus.

lg.l: To you I neede not; for you know't already;
But to my friend Sir Cautious, whom I honour,
And would not see so shipwrack'd, I may speake it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Will you undoe your daughter?

lg.l: My daughter; no you shall not put her upon me now.
She is your daughter sir: if I but call her mine,
Or suffer her to aske me a bare blessing,
You'll thrust her out: no, you adopted her
In your owne name, and made a Striker of her,
No more a Monylacks.
The beggarly Knight is desperate,
And should he out with it, my shame were endlesse:
This is the way or none to stop his mouth:
Tis but a money matter; stay a little

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.p: Goe not away sir Arnold, I must speak wi' yee.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I am not going sir.

lg.l: Be not a Mad-man here, here's forty peeces,
I know you use to strike for smaller summes:
But take it for your silence, and withall
My constant love, and my continuall friendship.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Give me your hand o' that; enough. Sir Arnold.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What say you to me sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What does he meane tro?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You must not have my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: No sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Vnlesse you meane to take anothers leavings.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Oh devillish reprobate.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How mean you that?

lg.l: Till she has buried first another husband,
And he leave her a widow: I am her father,
And claime a fathers interest in her choise;
And I have promis'd her to one already,
This very day, because I was not privy
To your proceedings; and have taken here
This faire assumpsit forty peeces sir;
You might admire how I should have 'hem otherwise.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Here's an impudent villaine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: For these I give a hundred, if you wed her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: To shew my love unto your daughter sir Ile pay't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Security in hand were good.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray lend me sir a hundred Peeces.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I dare not crosse this devill, I must fetch 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Twill ne're the lesse be my disparagement.

lg.l: What, when they know her grandfather dispos'd her,
That has the care of her, and gives her portion?
And then he can ha' but his money, can hee?
Oh but the wench, the wench, is such a wench,
Scarce two such marryed in a Diocesse,
In twice two twelve moneths, for right and straight ones.
There said you well; the straight ones I like well:
But those that men call right, or good ones, suffer
A by Construction.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Amongst the Iewd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But is here weight and number sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now the fiend stretch thee— you may take my word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Here I am wi' yee sir.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter Gilbert, Wat, Touchwood, Tom, Sam.

lg.l: Though you are fully bent to crosse the marriage,
Yet lets entreat you not to be too suddaine.
Till they come to the word, for better, for worse
I will not touch at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How now, what mates breake in upon us here?

lg.l: I come not as a guest sir, or spectator
To your great wedding, but o'the Kings affaires;
In which I must crave your assistance sir;
Deny't me, or my entrance, if you dare.
It is some weighty matter sure then.
But not to trouble your sconce with too much businesse
At once, pursue your owne, we will attend a while.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So it is sir,

lg.l: In that he has said well: I would the Bride
And Priest were come once; I am content they stand
For witnesses: what my kind Nephew are you here?
I thanke you for your plot, you see what 'tis come to.
Tis not all finish'd yet sir.
All in good time: the Bride is comming now.
You and your brother Poet are grown friends I see.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: But it may bee

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Whats he?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: A friend of Wats he brought for company.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: He was amongst 'hem too at the cheating exercise, and yonds the Knight himselfe; I know 'hem all I troe.

lg.l: And you'll stand to this, that your lost brother
Was Strikers Sister Audreyes sonne.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
I ha told you twonty times, and yet because you zay you'll stand my vrend, ile tell you more, she was with child with Tim bevore my vather married her (she brought him in her belly vrom this
towne here (where they get Children without veare or wit) but vor her money, and's owne credits zake, my vather was well apaid to keep it vor his owne; and no body knew to the Contrary, not Tim himzelfe to this houre.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then how camst thou to know it?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: My vather told it me upon his death-bed, and charg'd me on his blessing, never to open my mouth to man, woman, nor child, zo I told no body but vokes on't.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Wel, hold thy peace, tis an absolute wonder! Now to the wedding

div.head: Scene 12
div.stage: Enter Curate, Tramp. Ann. Fris. Reb.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: How's this? my bride in mourning habit, & her head in willow?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What's the meaning of it?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I said she was drest as never Bride was drest.

lg.l: A solemne shew, and suiting well the Scene!
She seems round bellied, and you marke it too.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My habit and my dressing suits my fortune.

lg.l: Pray sir doe your office, her conceit
We will know afterward.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Oh me; why Mistris look up, look up I say.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Clap her cheek, rub her nose.

sp.speaker: Fris
sp.p: Sprinkle cold water on her face.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Cut her lace, cut her lace, and bow her forward, so, so, so.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ile lay my life she quickens now with child.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What think you is the matter?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Women how is it with her?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, as with other women in her case.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How's that I pray you. you have bin doing something afore-hand sir.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Twill out, 'twill out,

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Have I?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It seems so by the story.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is she so drest?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You may leave laughing, it was your sonne that did it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I am undone, my house disgrac'd for ever.

lg.l: He knew't before hand, now I may declar't,
Speake o' thy Conscience, did it not?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Oh my heart.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Oh the hangman.

lg.l: Deceite becomes not dying men you know,
Into a whirlepoole of confusion
Sinke thou and all thy family, accursed miser.
This was a sure way now Sir Cautious,
To marry a maid, there's one i'the mothers belly.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Vh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You knew not where I could be so well fitted.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Vh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A rot o'your dissembling intrailes, spit 'hem out, you durst not strain your selfe to wind your whistle, your Doctor told you it would spend your spirits, so made me whistle for her

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Vh, uh, uh.

lg.l: Cheare up, cheare up, I may be friends wi'yee now:
Here's one has cause, and knowes the way to vexe yee,
To preserve life in you as well as I.
A hem, a hem, I will out-live you both:
This dayes vexation is enough for a life time.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And may it last thee to thy lives last houre.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Now let me talke wi'yee, and come you hither sir.

lg.l: I tell you true, your writings are so past, that if you goe
Not off by composition, you'll shake your whole estate.
Come hither Nephew,
Ile give thee a thousand pound, and take her off me.
I cannot with my reputation now:
But I will doe my best to worke a friend to 't.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Prethee doe, trye thy Poeticall souldier.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That Clowne come hither too: I feare I am trapt.

lg.l: Tis all as I have told you, and without question,
The man in question is your sisters sonne.
Would it might prove so, that I had yet a Nephew,
For now my Neece is lost.
Here's one shall find him out: or stretch a neck for't.
Sir Hugh you are charg'd for making of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now I am in.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: And more then so, for making him away.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Marry my brother Tim.

lg.l: Your patience yet a while: now gentlemen all,
Sir Cautious, and the rest, pray heare a story:
I have bin often urg'd to yield the cause
Of the long quarrell twixt this man and me:
Thirty yeares growth it has, he never durst
Reveale the reason; I being sullen would not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not tell it now?

lg.l: Indeed I will:
He had a sister (peace to her memory)
That in my youth I lov'd, shee me so much,
That we concluded, we were man and wife;
And dread lesse of all marriage lets, we did
Anticipate the pleasures of the bed.
Nay it shall out; briefly, she prov'd with child:
This covetous man then greedy of her portion,
(Of which for the most part he was possest)
Forces her with her shame to leave his house.
She makes her moane to me, I then (which since
I have with teares a thousand times repented)
Against my heart stood off, in hope to winne
Her Dowry from him: when she gentle soule
(Whom I must now bewaile) when she I say,
Not knowing my reserv'd intent, from him and me,
From friends, and all the world, for ought we knew,
Suddainly slipt away: after five yeares
I tooke another wife, by whom I had
The sonne, that has done that the woman sayes:
But where I left, if this mans tale be true,
She had a sonne, whom I demaund of you.
I shall have a kind of an uncle of you anon,
And you prove Tims vather.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: The young Gentleman that sir Hugh had in handling, is in the house, and Master Brittleware with him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Only we kept em back, till our more serious office were ended.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Pray em in, lets see him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, will it please you first to see a match quickely clapt up? This Gentleman whom I know every way deserving, were your Neece now in her prime of Fortune and of Vertue, desires to have her, and she him as much.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hee shall not have her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How can you say so?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He knowes his son I feare.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son shall make his fault good, and restore her honor to her if he lives, in meed for your faire sisters wrong and my misdeede, my son shall marry her; provided that he take her in his Conscience unstain'd by any other man.

sp.speaker: Stri.
