sp.p: On that condition Ile give her all the worldly good I have.

sp.speaker: Sam. Ann.
sp.p: We take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My sonne!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I take her not with all faults, but without any least blemish.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My supposed slaine: Thus I cast from me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Znailes a Cushion, how warme her belly has made it.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: And that all was but a plot 'twixt him and me, and these gentlemen: This paper may resolve you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Tis mine owne hand by which I instructed her by a dissembled way, to wound her honour.

lg.l: Which, to preserve my love, againe ide doe,
Hoping that you forgive it in me too.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Now am I cheated both wayes.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: The plot is finish'd: now thanks for your thousand pound sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are mine owne; welcome into my bosome.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Whoope, who comes here, my brother Tim drest like Master Maiors wife of Taunton-Deane.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Tis all I could get to scape without of the cozning house; and all I have to shew of foure hundred pound; but this certificate and this small jewel which my dying mother ga'me; and I had much ado to hide it from the Cheaters, to bring unto mine Vncle; which is he?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Lets see your token Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This is a jewell that I gave my Awdrey.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: That was my mother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And that's your vather he zaies.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And a gentleman? what a divellish deale of mony might I ha sav'd! for gentle-men let me tell you, I have been cozen'd black and blew; backe-guld and belly-guld; and have nothing left me but a little bare Complement to live upon, as I am a cleare gentleman.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Will you bestow some of it upon me.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Vncle you shall: First ile give you a hit at single Rapier complement: and then a wipe or two with the Back-sword Complement and I ha done.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Pray begin.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Striker the grave Magistrate (if my apprehension deale fairely with me) whose prayses reach to Heaven, for the faire distribution of equall justice: the poore mans Sanctuary, the righter of Widdowe's, and the Orphans wrongs.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Enough, enough, you have sayd very well.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Note you yond justice sits upon the Bench?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, I do note him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
The Stockes were fitter for him: the most corrupted fellow
about the Suburbs, his conscience is stewd in Bribes, all his poore neigbours curse him; tis though the keeps a whoor now at three score.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A very Westerne Southsayer, thou art mine owne.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: His Neece is much suspected.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay there you went too farre, this is his Neece, and my daughter now.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I know no Neece he has, I speak but backsword complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You put me wel in mind though, here's one, that ere the Parson and we part, ile make an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And for your part sir Hugh, you shall make satisfaction, and bring in your Confederates.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Here's one that came to complaine of me for my Robes here, but I ha lost my small acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Ile answer for him too, & give you al the satisfaction that I can

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What you cannot shall be remitted, we have all our faults.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And have I found thee Beck in so good company?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I Iacke, be you jealous no more, and I will long no more to vexe thee.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Live lovingly and honestly I charge you, or come not at mee when I am married.

lg.l: This yonker ile take care for,
And make him a new gentleman by new breeding,
Without the Dyet, bathing, purge, or bleeding.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet Sir I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ile home againe then and make Tanton ring on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Our quarrell in this peece of folly ends.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He parted us, and he has made us friends.

lg.l: Nephew, and Gentlemen, I am friends with all,
You had your plot upon me, I had mine.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Lets in, and end all differences in wine.

lg.l: AT first we made no boast, and still we feare,
We have not answer'd expectation here,
Yet give us leave to hope, as hope to live,
That you will grace, as well as Iustice give.
We do not dare your Iudgments now: for we
Know lookers on more then the Gamsters see;
And what ere Poets write, we Act, or say,
Tis only in your hands to Crowne a Play.
